The company plans to introduce UK-specific savings accounts and financial education resources. While the UK market may not replicate the success seen in the US, Robinhood's existing technology and services may lower the cost of serving UK customers. Initial subsidization from the US business is expected.

title: Building in Public and Showing Your Receipts: Differentiation in the Age of Grifters
summary: The article discusses the dual nature of social media, highlighting the exposure to both genuine and fraudulent individuals. It emphasizes the thin line between exaggeration and dishonesty, particularly in the context of tech startup founders and influencers. The author advocates for "building in public" as a credible alternative, citing the example of Iman Gadzhi, who has transparently documented his entrepreneurial journey on social media. The concept of "building in public" involves sharing stories openly to attract like-minded individuals and nurture relationships, while also demonstrating both successes and failures. The article underscores the importance of authenticity, hard work, and substantiating claims to establish genuine trust and brand identity.

title: Lenders of Last Resort
summary: Silvergate Capital, a bank heavily involved with the crypto community, has completed the repayment of all remaining depositors after facing a significant exodus of funds. The bank's ties to the crypto community led to a massive withdrawal of deposits, resulting in a struggle to access cash quickly enough to meet demand. To stay afloat, Silvergate turned to the Federal Home Loan Bank in San Francisco for special loans, which it later repaid. However, this situation has raised concerns about the role and operations of the Federal Home Loan Banks, prompting proposals for reform from the Federal Housing Finance Agency. The article highlights the significant but relatively unknown power of the Federal Home Loan Banks, which hold $1.3 trillion in assets.

title: A Haze of Alcohol and Confusion
summary: The article discusses the cult anime film "Roujin Z" from 1991, highlighting its unique blend of social satire, comedy, and giant robot elements. The film, written by Katsuhiro Otomo and directed by Hiroyuki Kitakubo, features a robotic hospital bed, the Z-001 unit, going out of control with an old man inside. The story follows a nursing student's race to save him, offering a satirical take on Japan's aging population and healthcare system. The article also mentions Roger Ebert's positive review of the film and promises to delve into the detailed story of how "Roujin Z" came to be.

title: Meat in the Middle
summary: The article discusses the upcoming COP28 in the UAE and the push to lower global carbon emissions, particularly through curbing meat consumption. It highlights the clash between environmental extremism and political resistance, as well as the potential impact on cultural and political landscapes. The piece questions the feasibility and consequences of enforcing reduced meat consumption, especially in affluent nations, and predicts escalating conflict over this issue. It emphasizes the centrality of food in cultural identity and the potential implications of limiting global meat consumption. The article also mentions the organization Clim-Eat and its founder's advocacy for climate action in food systems.

title: "Inflation Is Your Fault" And Other Self-Loathing Liberal Lies
summary: The article is a critique of The Atlantic's blaming of everyday Americans for inflation. The author argues that inflation is a result of the expansion of the money supply during Covid, not excessive spending. They criticize The Atlantic for overlooking this and for scapegoating the middle and lower class. The author predicts a potential deflationary depression and questions the competence of the Federal Reserve. They highlight the irony of The Atlantic's stance and assert that the blame lies with those in power, not the general public. The article concludes with a sarcastic comparison between the author and the supposed "geniuses" responsible for economic policies.

title: Cambodia’s Ream Naval Base: New Chinese Trojan Horse?
summary: China is expanding Cambodia's Ream Naval Base as part of its "String of Pearls" strategy to challenge the US and establish itself as a blue-water maritime power. This move has raised concerns among neighboring countries and the US. China's involvement in Ream marks its second overseas military base and includes the construction of a pier long enough to dock an aircraft carrier and a large drydock. The base's strategic significance is debated, with some experts questioning its practicality for China's naval power projection. Despite denials from China and Cambodia, satellite imagery and other developments suggest the potential for Ream to become a de-facto Chinese overseas naval base. This expansion is part of China's broader efforts to imprint its influence on port facilities worldwide, enabling sustained deployment of naval forces. The situation has prompted calls for regional countries to band together in response to China's maritime claims. The article is written by Andy Wong Ming Jun, a specialist in naval strategy with a Master's Degree in International Security from the University of Bath.

title: The Ominous Promise of AI
summary: In 2016, 18 privacy groups filed complaints with the US Federal Trade Commission and the European Union against Genesis Toys and Nuance, alleging deceptive practices and privacy law violations related to the recording of children's voices by toys like i-Que and My Friend Cayla.

title: Gaza: China's Opening
summary: Arab and Muslim ministers' visit to Beijing highlights China's growing influence in the Middle East, as it seeks deeper economic and political engagement with Arab countries. This shift is evident in the wake of the failure of the US-led Abraham Accords and the subsequent conflict in Palestine. China's support for the Palestinian cause has led to increased diplomatic activity and engagement with Arab states, as it aims to capitalize on Washington's failure and expand its footprint in the region. China's Belt & Road Initiative (BRI) and extensive projects in the Middle East further solidify its position. Despite criticism over its treatment of Muslims domestically, China's alignment with the Arab world serves its strategic interests. This convergence presents an opportunity for China to challenge US influence and strengthen ties with a lucrative market and key oil supplier. The recent pause in fighting in Palestine is partly attributed to China's diplomacy, further underscoring its growing role in the region.

title: BOOK REVIEW: Things You May Find Hidden in My Ear (Poems from Gaza)
summary: Mosab Abu Toha, a poet from Gaza, won the Derek Walcott Prize for his debut poetry collection, "Things You May Find Hidden in My Ear: Poems from Gaza." His poems reflect the pain of living in Gaza under siege, evoking the experiences of loss, violence, and resilience. The collection offers a glimpse into the lives of besieged people in Gaza, particularly children, amidst relentless Israeli bombings. Despite the bleakness, the poetry also conveys hope and resilience. Mosab's social media posts reflect the ongoing devastation and suffering in Gaza, with recent updates about surviving bombings. His work provides a poignant portrayal of life in Gaza, capturing the trauma, loss, and perseverance of its people.

title: Okay people, I need your help
summary: Dr. Katelyn Jetelina reflects on the success of her public health newsletter, "Your Local Epidemiologist," as it enters its fourth year. Despite the growing subscriber base, she expresses burnout from writing about Covid-19 and seeks new directions for the newsletter in 2024. She emphasizes the need to sustain interest in public health beyond the pandemic and invites reader input through a survey. Dr. Jetelina credits the audience for driving the content's success and expresses gratitude for their ongoing support. She aims to continue providing evidence-based public health information and encourages subscriptions to sustain the newsletter.

title: Investment Idea #14
summary: The article discusses non-stock investments as a form of portfolio insurance in case of a financial system collapse. It highlights the historical examples of hyperinflation in Venezuela and the potential risk of global fiat currency system collapse. The author emphasizes the importance of holding cash for optionality and discusses the possibility of a doomsday scenario like the Great Depression or WWIII impacting financial assets. The article also mentions the Israel-Hamas war.

title: Business Day TV Daily Stock Picks (October 2023)
summary: The article discusses Business Day TV's Daily Stock Pick videos, featuring South African stock picks and companies leaving the country. It covers stocks like Sibanye-Stillwater, TFG Limited, MultiChoice Group, Anglo-American, and others. It also mentions the closure of the Franklin FTSE South Africa ETF and the termination of Business Day TV's YouTube channel. The article provides details about Sibanye-Stillwater and TFG Limited, including their stock picks and forward P/E and dividend yields. It also discusses MultiChoice Group and Anglo-American, with insights from various fund managers. Additionally, it includes links to relevant resources for further information.

title: Broadening the aperture of how you look at life
summary: The article discusses an interview about the book "Soul in the Game: The Art of a Meaningful Life" by Vitaliy Katsenelson, featuring a memorable moment with his daughter. The interview was conducted by Rabbi Ray Zwerin, a lifelong learner and accomplished individual. Katsenelson reflects on the wisdom and writing of Rabbi Zwerin, highlighting the broad perspective and enlightenment offered in his book "40 Years of Wondering." The article also mentions the passing of Charlie Munger and a special concert by the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra. Additionally, it promotes the availability of prints by Naum Katsenelson and Alex Katsenelson. The article concludes with information about Vitaliy Katsenelson's professional background and publications.

title: Pre-Three Red Lines banks sought to limit lending to developers
summary: The article discusses the economic transformation in China, emphasizing the need to move away from heavy reliance on infrastructure and real estate for higher growth. It highlights the challenges faced by Chinese banks in obtaining loans, particularly the requirement for good collateral, often in the form of property. The history and reasons behind property being a lucrative investment are explored, along with the implications for future returns. Additionally, it touches on the availability and cost of bank loans compared to other credit funding sources in China. The overall tone suggests a pessimistic outlook on property prices and emphasizes the advantages of bank loans for leveraged buyers.

title: Weekend thoughts: disruptors disrupted
summary: The article discusses the financial distress faced by WeWork and Spirit, and the potential impact of their struggles on their respective industries. It questions whether businesses that were previously unprofitable due to uneconomic competition might become more profitable as interest rates rise and unsustainable competitors leave the market. The article also highlights examples such as IWG, rental car companies, and banks that could benefit from the restructuring of their competitors. It emphasizes the potential for finding undervalued companies that could see increased profitability as their competitors retrench. The author reflects on the significant economic shifts over the past 18 months and the opportunities they present for identifying businesses with improved future prospects.

title: Robust Contracting & Linear Programming
summary: The article discusses a project involving Ashwin Kambhampati, Juuso Toikka, and the author, which led to a new proof of Carroll's main result. The main result is shown to be a consequence of linear programming duality. The article delves into the concept of contracts chosen by the principal, the agent's expected payoff, and Nature's optimization problem formulated as a linear program. It presents a lemma and a theorem related to admissible contracts and optimal solutions. The article concludes by discussing the dual to Nature's optimization problem and providing a proof for a specific case.

title: Vibes vs. data
summary: The article discusses the debate surrounding the U.S. economy's performance, with Biden supporters highlighting low unemployment and rising wages, while opponents argue that the 2021-22 inflation has negatively impacted consumer confidence. The author emphasizes that despite positive economic indicators, negative narratives and sentiments are influencing public perception. The article also critiques a Twitter thread's misinterpretation of economic data, highlighting how negative narratives can distort understanding. It further explores the discrepancy between personal financial satisfaction and negative beliefs about the national economy, attributing this to the influence of "vibes" and negativity bias in media. The author expresses concern about combating these negative narratives and ensuring the public is informed about the actual economic situation.

title: The Most Important Inflation Indicator Shows More Cooling Ahead
summary: The article discusses the impact of rising rents on the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and the limitations of official data on shelter prices. It introduces the New Tenant Rent Index (NTR) as a more accurate measure of current rental inflation, showing a significant disinflation in rent prices. Private measures also support the normalization of price pressures in the housing market. However, the precise pace and timing of the upcoming deceleration in official rent prices are uncertain due to limited historical data. The relationship between cyclical growth in employment/wages and housing inflation is highlighted, indicating a natural deceleration in NTR following a slower labor market. The NTR, originally an academic tool, has gained public interest and will now be published quarterly, providing high-frequency data on rent inflation. The article encourages readers to subscribe for new posts on economic data analysis.

title: Priced to Outperform Perfection: The Home Depot Circa 1999
summary: The article discusses the risk of market saturation for successful businesses, using Home Depot as an example. It explores the concept of investor return and the valuation of the company based on store count and potential growth. The analysis estimates potential earnings and market valuation based on different scenarios, highlighting the importance of considering prospective return and the risk associated with stock prices. Ultimately, it emphasizes the significance of considering the price paid for a company and the associated risk, using Home Depot's historical performance as a case study. The article provides a detailed financial analysis and highlights the importance of conservative assumptions in investment decisions.

title: The U.S. Economy Is Booming. Or Stagnating? The Mystery of the Missing Interest.
summary: The article discusses the significant statistical discrepancy in the U.S. economy's growth, with a $843 billion swing between expenditure-based GDP/NDP and income-based GDI/NDI estimates. The Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) is believed to have miscalculated interest payments by businesses, leading to this discrepancy. Previous revisions and comprehensive NIPA revisions have attempted to address this issue, but the recent gap remains unexplained. The discrepancy is attributed to revisions in wage income, consumer spending, services exports, dividend payout ratio, and profit estimates. The article emphasizes that the recent gap is concentrated in components of NDI prone to measurement errors and revisions, highlighting the need for further investigation.

title: Lessons from 2023: RIP "Fast Energy Transition" Narrative
summary: The article discusses the key takeaways from the 2023 energy transition, highlighting the collapse of new energy equities and the growing recognition of the substantial energy demand growth in developing countries. It emphasizes the need for a new narrative that addresses the unmet energy needs of the majority of the world's population and criticizes unrealistic net zero scenarios and unreliable energy metrics. The article also delves into China's energy approach, emphasizing the necessity of all forms of energy to meet the substantial energy needs of developing nations. It concludes by advocating for a pragmatic and inclusive approach to energy outlook and policy. The author also reflects on the 2-year anniversary of the publication and shares personal insights. The article provides a critical perspective on energy transition and advocates for a balanced and realistic approach to energy policy and investment.

title: Where to Malaysia?
summary: The article discusses the potential shift towards a Malay-centric government in Malaysia, driven by changing demographics. It predicts a future where the Malay state will be characterized by increased influence of the Royal households and Ulama, leading to a more conservative and compliant society. The consequences of this shift include potential secession discussions in East Malaysian states, limited freedom of expression, economic challenges, and reduced international appeal. The article warns of a potential decline in foreign investment and increased instability within the elite Malay polity. Overall, it paints a picture of a future Malay state with significant societal and economic implications.

title: Has Dr Zaliha Mustafa has committed treason?
summary: The article discusses Dr. Zaliha Mustafa's failure to reject amendments to the International Health Regulations (IHRs) adopted by the World Health Assembly (WHA) on May 27, 2022. It highlights the influence of career bureaucrats within the Ministry of Health, the misleading statements made by the Minister for Health in parliament, and the potential consequences of not rejecting the amendments. The article also mentions the influence of former Director General Noor Hisham Abdullah and Khairy Jamaluddin within the Ministry of Health, as well as the fate of Dr. Zaliha in light of these developments. Additionally, it raises concerns about Malaysia's potential subservience to global organizations and the implications for the country's sovereignty.

title: Anwar is trying to destroy Bersatu before GE16
summary: The article discusses the declining popularity of the 'unity government' and the potential for Anwar to secure a second term as prime minister by weakening the Bersatu party within the Perikatan Nasional (PN) coalition. It highlights Anwar's Machiavellian tactics, including enticing Bersatu MPs to defect and the government's controversial actions to maintain power. The article also raises concerns about the potential consequences of Anwar's strategies, including the risk of PAS making significant gains in the next general election. Overall, it emphasizes the political maneuvering and power struggles within the Malaysian government, with a focus on Anwar's efforts to secure a second term as prime minister.

title: Landslide win for PAS in Kemaman
summary: The Kemaman by-election resulted in a significant defeat for Raja Mohamed Affandi Raja Mohamed Noor of UMNO, by Ahmad Samsuri Mokhtar of PAS, who won by a large majority. The challenge to the 2022 general election results led to electoral humiliation for UMNO and raised questions about the Madani government's democratic legitimacy. The result also highlighted Ahmad Samsuri as a potential future leader in federal politics. The outcome indicates a decline in support for Anwar's PKR and UMNO, with PAS emerging as a strong force. The article also discusses the potential need for UMNO to reinvent itself and the implications for Najib Razak. Overall, the results suggest a shift in political dynamics and potential challenges for various parties in the upcoming general election.

title: 463: Market Clustering, Income & Happiness, Cloudflare NOT 4th Cloud, Amazon, EVs, Furnace Scams, SDXL Turbo, Geothermal, and Pacing
summary: The article discusses the author's experience as a Wikipedia editor and the debates within the community about content. It also touches on the band The Ocean's approach to releasing dual versions of their albums and the concept of compression versus uncompression in achieving deep happiness. The author shares a personal experience of gaining insight from a podcast episode and reflects on the impact of macro sentiment on investment decisions. The article also mentions the clustering of best and worst market days and the challenge of market timing. Overall, it delves into various topics including music, mental frames, happiness, and investment strategies.

title: Recent Disparities in Earnings and Employment
summary: The article discusses the recent release of Equitable Growth Indicators (EGIs) by the New York Fed, focusing on gender disparities in the labor market at national and regional levels. It examines trends in gender wage and employment gaps since the pandemic, using data from January 2019 to October 2023. The analysis reveals that while the gender employment and earnings gaps widened during the pandemic, they have since decreased, with the regional disparities declining more sharply than the national ones. The rise of remote work and its impact on women's labor market participation and earnings is also explored. The findings suggest that remote work may have provided a "silver lining" for women's labor market outcomes. The article is authored by Rajashri Chakrabarti, Kasey Chatterji-Len, Dan Garcia, and Maxim Pinkovskiy. The full article can be accessed at https://libertystreeteconomics.newyorkfed.org/2023/12/recent-disparities-in-earnings-and-employment/.

title: Split Share Corporations: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly
summary: The article discusses the author's simple approach to investing, focusing on Canadian dividend-paying stocks and a conservative, straightforward strategy. The author emphasizes the value of simplicity in investing, cautioning against complex products and strategies that often underperform and incur high fees. The article also mentions the author's exploration of alternate investments like covered call ETFs and closed-end funds, while questioning the worth of split share corporations. The author aims to provide guidance and simplify the investment process for retail investors, highlighting the challenges of achieving decent results in long-term investing.

title: 5 Charlie Munger Lessons That Made Me a Better Investor
summary: The article discusses the author's admiration for Charlie Munger, who recently passed away, and the impact of Munger's wisdom on the author's life. The author reflects on five key lessons learned from Munger, including the importance of financial independence, the "no asshole" rule, the concept of inversion, the value of patience in investing, and the significance of discipline in managing cash. The author also shares personal experiences and insights gained from Munger's teachings, expressing gratitude for his influence. The article concludes with a tribute to Munger's legacy and offers a subscription as a holiday gift idea.

title: Nvidia’s China Business is Important to US Geopolitical Positioning
summary: The article discusses the application of Sun Tzu's military strategy, 围三阙一, in the context of US technology sanctions affecting AI entrepreneurs in China. It highlights the impact of the sanctions on Nvidia's China business and the shift towards Huawei's Ascend chips. The article emphasizes the unintended consequences of the sanctions, leading to the consolidation of Chinese firms around Huawei and the potential long-term implications for US geopolitical strategy. It also touches on Huawei's strategic moves to expand its reach and compete with Nvidia. The author suggests that the US may need to reconsider its approach to advance its long-term interests vis-a-vis China.

title: The Dog of the Dow
summary: The article discusses the diminishing significance of the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) due to its price-weighted methodology and limited sample size of 30 large-cap companies. Despite this, the index still offers valuable insights into the performance of major industry players and sectors. The recent surge in the DJIA has brought it close to its all-time highs, largely influenced by tech giants like Apple and Microsoft, which dominate the index's market capitalization and earnings. However, the article also highlights J.P. Morgan Chase as an undervalued company within the index, trading at a significantly lower forward P/E ratio compared to Apple and Microsoft. The focus on relative valuations within the index reveals the overvalued and undervalued companies, with Apple and Microsoft at the top and J.P. Morgan Chase at the bottom.

title: Riassunto settimanale 03/12/2023
summary: The article discusses the strong performance of global stock markets in November, with the US market marking its best sixth month of positive performance since 1993. European indices also ended positively, with the Ftsemib approaching the 30,000-point threshold. However, Chinese stock indices remained stagnant. The decrease in interest rates, along with moderate consumer price levels, boosted confidence in a soft landing for the US economy. Additionally, the article highlights the significant strengthening of the yen against major currencies and the favorable impact on precious metals due to the weakening dollar and declining interest rates. The article also pays tribute to Charlie Munger, a prominent investor and Berkshire Hathaway chairman, emphasizing his resilience and rational approach to life. It concludes with book recommendations about Munger's life and greatness.

title: Robust Contracting & Linear Programming
summary: The article discusses a project involving Ashwin Kambhampati, Juuso Toikka, and the author, which led to a new proof of Carroll's main result. The proof demonstrates how the result is a consequence of linear programming duality. It delves into the concept of contracts chosen by the principal and actions of the agent, presenting a linear program formulated by Nature to minimize the principal's payoff. The article then analyzes Nature's problem under a linear contract and a general contract, providing a lemma and a theorem related to admissible contracts and optimal solutions. The article concludes with a proof related to the general contract.

title: Recent Disparities in Earnings and Employment
summary: The article discusses the recent release of Equitable Growth Indicators (EGIs) by the New York Fed, focusing on gender disparities in the labor market at national and regional levels. It examines the evolution of gender wage and employment gaps since the pandemic, finding that the gaps have declined more sharply in the region than nationally. The article also analyzes the impact of remote work on gender gaps and highlights the decline in gender earnings gaps at both levels. The findings suggest that the pandemic and the rise of remote work have led to decreased gender gaps in employment and earnings, particularly in the region. The authors are Rajashri Chakrabarti, Kasey Chatterji-Len, Dan Garcia, and Maxim Pinkovskiy. The article provides detailed data analysis and charts to support its findings.

title: 17 Great Stock Pitches (16th-30th Nov)⚡
summary: Welcome to another edition of the Capital Employed Newsletter. The newsletter features quotes, interviews with fund managers, and offers discounts on investment platforms like Sharesight and Koyfin. It also highlights stock pitches on various companies including Tel-Aviv Stock Exchange, OssDsign, Medistim, GAN, Vestis, Playmates Toys, and others. The article concludes with an invitation to connect on social media and a disclaimer stating that the content is for informational purposes and not investment advice.

title: Substack is for video
summary: The article discusses Substack's evolution beyond newsletters to become a platform for various creative works, including podcasts and now video content. It emphasizes Substack's focus on empowering creators with direct subscriber relationships, content ownership, and monetization opportunities. The platform's new video features, such as podcast uploading, flexible paywalls, and design enhancements, aim to support subscriber-supported video content. Substack's network, driving a significant portion of subscriptions, offers creators immediate access to a large subscriber base without relinquishing ownership or control. The article highlights how Substack's model challenges the dynamics of major online platforms, providing creators with a more stable and lucrative alternative. It concludes by expressing anticipation for the future of video content on Substack.

title: Tenured Georgetown professor scrubbed from faculty directory following Karlstack investigation
summary: The article discusses a major finance-academia scandal involving a paper by Bai, Bali, and Wen (BBW) in the "Journal of Financial Economics", which contained significant errors leading to its retraction. The scandal raises concerns about academic integrity and the impact on finance research, with Georgetown University, the authors' institution, notably silent on the matter. Dr. Quan Wen, one of the authors, has been removed from Georgetown's faculty and finance directories, sparking speculation about his potential resignation or firing. Additionally, a corrigendum to Turan Bali's article has been issued, representing a broader corrective action in the field. The author criticizes the decision to issue a correction instead of a full retraction, highlighting the low bar for accountability in finance. The article emphasizes the widespread implications of the scandal, with numerous papers citing BBW now being questioned, and the broader issue of flawed research in the field.

title: The Digest #177
summary: Charlie Munger, Warren Buffett's partner, passed away, prompting a tribute issue of The Digest. The issue compiles articles and podcasts celebrating Munger's life and career, including a book review, reflections, and interviews. The articles cover Munger's investment success, his partnership with Buffett, and his influence on others. The podcasts feature discussions with Munger and reflections on his impact. Additionally, the issue highlights Munger's letters to Blue Chip Stamps shareholders, showcasing his rare candor and integrity. The tribute issue serves as a comprehensive homage to Munger's legacy and influence in the business world.

title: The Digest #178
summary: The article is about Berkshire Hathaway's countersuit against Pilot's founders, alleging that Jimmy Haslam promised "massive side payments" to high-level Pilot employees to inflate short-term profits. This affects the calculation of earnings for 2023 and the price of the Haslam family's remaining stake. The article also includes various other topics such as Meta's alleged manipulation of teen vulnerabilities, Washington's scrapped plan to save homeowners money, and other diverse content including podcasts and essays. The Digest #177 was dedicated to Charlie Munger, and the current installment includes items from earlier in the week. The article encourages readers to support the publication by purchasing a subscription.

title: Rover ($ROVR) being acquired by Blackstone for $11.00/share
summary: The article discusses the author's bullish stance on ROVR after strong Q3 earnings, leading to a 30% position in the company. However, Blackstone's acquisition of ROVR at $11.00 per share, a 30% premium, prompted the author to sell at $11.05. The author is discontinuing the planned part 2 of the ROVR deep dive and is seeking new investment opportunities, particularly in small/mid caps. Large cap companies with high valuations are deemed unattractive, and the author invites suggestions for small/mid cap stocks with significant upside potential. The article concludes with a request for non-speculative stock recommendations.

title: China’s Political Discourse September 2023: Struggling With Negotiation in the US-China Relationship
summary: The article discusses the discourse in China's state media regarding the US-China relationship in September 2023, highlighting a shift in tone from criticism to seeking a stable relationship. It also delves into the reinforcement of discipline within the CCP leadership, focusing on the "list system" for Party leaders and cadres. Additionally, it covers the draft revisions of the Public Security Administration Punishments Law, which faced criticism for vague formulations. The article also analyzes the discourse scale of CCP terminologies and the centrality index of China's top leaders, along with mentions of foreign leaders in the People's Daily. The article provides a comprehensive overview of the political and diplomatic landscape in China during September 2023.

title: Terra Incognita
summary: The article discusses the unprecedented dynamics driving the US economy, leading to divergent views on its future trajectory. It outlines three main scenarios: reacceleration, soft landing, and recession, each with its reasoning, pushback, and investment implications. The author attempts to synthesize these scenarios, predicting a likely slowdown with potential recessionary impacts, but with ample room for the Fed to respond. The article emphasizes the importance of market signals, particularly the stocks vs. bonds ratio and the S&P 500 trendline, in determining the future economic regime. The author then shares their investment decisions, including selling long positions, holding a long Yen position, and buying equity index put spreads, oil majors, TIPS, and Gold puts. The article concludes by highlighting the uncertainty and interdependence of the economic world and the need for positioning to benefit from a range of possible outcomes.

title: Emerging Markets Monitor - November 29
summary: Brazil's state-controlled oil company, Petrobras, plans to invest $102 billion by 2028 to position itself as a major global oil power. The investment will focus on production and exploration, particularly in deep water reserves off the coast of Rio de Janeiro and potential new deposits near the Amazon river. Meanwhile, Argentina's president-elect, Javier Milei, seeks radical economic reforms and a pro-U.S. foreign policy, as he aims to lead the country out of crisis. In the climate change arena, the COP-28 President-designate calls for maximum ambition and urgent action to tackle climate change, emphasizing the need for firm commitments to finance mitigation efforts. Additionally, Saudi Arabia has offered to boost cooperation and invest in Iran's economy if Iran stops its regional proxies from escalating the Israel-Hamas conflict. Lastly, Asia's first Saudi Arabia ETF made a successful debut in Hong Kong, marking a milestone in the partnership between the Middle East and Asian financial markets.

title: Illustrated Frankenstein - Chapter 22
summary: The article is an excerpt from "Frankenstein" by Mary Shelley, where the protagonist, Victor Frankenstein, reflects on his guilt and despair over the deaths caused by his creation, the monster. He struggles with the impending marriage to his cousin, Elizabeth, fearing for her safety due to the monster's threat. Despite his inner turmoil, he maintains a facade of happiness for Elizabeth's sake. The narrative portrays his internal conflict, remorse, and the ominous foreshadowing of impending tragedy. The article also includes a letter from Elizabeth expressing her concerns and affection for Victor. As the wedding day approaches, Victor's anxiety grows, and the narrative sets the stage for the tragic events to come.

title: As the US Treasury Runs Out of Creditors, Its Options Dwindle
summary: The article discusses the US Treasury's debt spiral due to excessive government spending, leading to deepening deficits and a mountain of debt. With tax revenues not keeping up, the government must borrow, causing interest payments to soar. The US Treasury is facing a dwindling customer base for its debt, including the Fed and foreign governments. As a result, upcoming Treasury auctions and maturing debt pose significant challenges. The article outlines potential scenarios, including a financial crisis, debt crisis, or a "soft default" by the US government. The author emphasizes the uncertainty surrounding the Fed's actions and the consequences of reckless fiscal and monetary policies. The article highlights the potential for a combination of these scenarios to unfold in 2024 and beyond. The author, Dr. Jonathan Newman, is a Fellow at the Mises Institute, with a focus on Austrian economics, inflation, and business cycles.

title: Has Covid messed with our immune systems?
summary: The article discusses the resurgence of "regular" viruses like flu and RSV in China and the US, attributing it to "immunity debt" caused by pandemic control measures. It explores the impact of Covid-19 on the immune system, addressing concerns about immunocompromise and the rise in pediatric infections. While some changes in immune cells post-Covid-19 are noted, severe cases causing immunocompromise are rare. The article emphasizes the need to stay updated on vaccines and take precautions against respiratory viruses to mitigate the impact of "immunity debt" on population health. The author, Dr. Katelyn Jetelina, aims to translate public health information for evidence-based decision-making.

title: Waiting for Godot
summary: The article discusses the application of a concept from the play "Waiting for Godot" to investment themes, particularly in the energy sector. The author argues against the imminent decline of fossil fuels, citing the law of increasing energy density favoring fossil fuels, the challenges in transitioning to green metals, and the misconception of the energy sector being disrupted like other industries. The author predicts that the world will use more renewable energy in the future but also more fossil fuels due to increasing energy demand. The article emphasizes the potential investment opportunities in traditional energy companies.

title: Vita Coco: Testing The Moat
summary: The article discusses Vita Coco's sustainable supply chain advantages and the impact of the loss and subsequent restoration of its distribution agreement with Costco. The author questions the strength of Vita Coco's competitive positioning following the loss of the Costco private label business. The renewed deal with Costco is seen as a positive development, but uncertainties remain regarding its sustainability. Despite this, having a renewed deal with Costco is considered better than the alternative. Vita Coco's Q3 FY23 revenues increased by 11% YoY, driven by growth in private label and branded Vita Coco businesses. The company's dominant position in the U.S. coconut water category is highlighted, with a 50% market share.

Munger's influence led to the popularization of investment concepts such as 'Moats' and 'The Latticework of Mental Models'. He played a crucial role in key investments, including Blue Chip Stamps and See's Candies, and advocated for multi-disciplinary thinking. Known for his blunt candor, Munger's intellectual honesty and insights have left a lasting impact on the investing world. His legacy as an iconic figure will be deeply missed by millions of value investors worldwide.

title: Treasury Bill Supply and ON RRP Investment
summary: The article discusses the increase in take-up at the Federal Reserve’s Overnight Reverse Repo Facility (ON RRP) due to a reduction in the supply of U.S. Treasury bills (T-bills). Money market mutual funds (MMFs) responded to the decrease in T-bill supply by investing more at the ON RRP, leading to the overall increased take-up. The shortage of T-bills limited MMFs' investment options, making the ON RRP an attractive alternative. Regression analysis shows that a decrease in T-bill issuance led government MMFs to increase their ON RRP investment significantly more than prime MMFs. The effect is economically important, with government MMFs' ON RRP investment increasing by $750 billion relative to prime MMFs, against a total increase in ON RRP take-up of $2.2 trillion. The authors are from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's Research and Statistics Group and a Ph.D. student in business economics at Harvard University. The full article can be found at https://libertystreeteconomics.newyorkfed.org/2023/11/treasury-bill-supply-and-on-rrp-investment/.

title: Treasury Bill Supply and ON RRP Investment
summary: The article discusses the increase in take-up at the Federal Reserve’s Overnight Reverse Repo Facility (ON RRP) and its relation to the supply of U.S. Treasury bills (T-bills). It explains how the reduction in T-bill supply led money market mutual funds (MMFs) to invest more at the ON RRP, contributing to the overall increased take-up. The article highlights the significant growth in MMFs' demand for Treasury securities and the impact of T-bill supply decrease after the COVID-19 crisis. It also presents a regression analysis showing that a decrease in T-bill issuance led government MMFs to increase their ON RRP investment more than prime MMFs. The shortage of T-bills pushed MMFs to increase their investment at the ON RRP facility, particularly due to the reduced T-bill issuance. The authors are affiliated with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's Research and Statistics Group. The Gaza conflict has also impacted US-China competition, potentially providing China with breathing space for deeper competition with the US. Additionally, it may freeze attempts to create a new trade corridor from India to Europe, affecting Washington's infrastructure plan. Additionally, the KMT's vice presidential candidate, Jaw Shau-kong, known for his strong pro-China views, is using fear tactics to sway voters, warning of potential conflict and instability under continued DPP rule. title: Vaccine disparities are worse post-emergency

It compares U.S. vaccination rates unfavorably with the U.K. and delves into inequities within the U.S., particularly among communities of color, rural areas, and different socioeconomic groups. The article emphasizes the widening disparities and new barriers to vaccine access, underscoring the amplified gaps in access and uptake due to the commercialization of vaccines. It calls for systemic changes to address these inequities and ensure fair resource distribution, expressing concern about the nation's vaccine system during non-emergency times. The piece is signed by "Your Local Epidemiologist (YLE)" and the team at Marin County Health Department, and is written by Dr. Katelyn Jetelina, an epidemiologist, with the goal of translating public health information for evidence-based decision-making.

title: California Survey I
summary: Transit ridership in the Los Angeles area surged after a freeway closure, highlighting the competition between private vehicles and public transportation. The LA Metro experienced a 10% increase in passengers following the closure of the Santa Monica Freeway, which was repaired in a remarkably short time. Despite ongoing efforts to expand the rail system, the Metro competes with a well-funded highway system. California's transportation budget is significantly lower than the state's highway spending, and the region lacks user fees for federal highways. The state has taken steps to discourage driving through extra fees and increased petrol taxes, leading to a decline in petrol demand and a rise in Metro ridership. The article suggests the introduction of congestion fees and user fees for driving to address the collective action problem of reducing emissions. It also discusses the potential for rapid emissions decline through strong action against existing vehicles, as seen in Europe. The article emphasizes the need for policy measures to nudge car drivers towards fewer miles driven and achieve meaningful emissions reductions.

The piece concludes by cautioning investors about the complexities and potential pitfalls of leverage.

title: Why there must be a Royal Commission into the murder of Altantaya Shaariibuu
summary: The article discusses the release of Sirul Azhar Umar from an Australian detention center and the controversy surrounding his involvement in the murder of Altantuya. Sirul claims innocence and implicates high-ranking authorities, creating a dilemma for both Australia and Malaysia. The article highlights the need for a Royal Commission to uncover the truth behind Altantuya's murder, implicating political figures including Najib Razak and his aide-de-camp. Various unanswered questions and suspicious circumstances surrounding the case are also raised, including the mysterious disappearance of Sirul's statutory declaration and the lack of action by the current home minister. The article concludes by emphasizing the necessity of a Royal Commission of Inquiry to address these unresolved issues.

title: Deep Dive: Publicis Groupe (PUB, PUBGY)
summary: The article discusses Publicis Groupe (PUB), a major advertising agency based in Paris, with a significant presence in North America. It has made strategic acquisitions to position itself in the evolving digital advertising landscape. Despite concerns about a potential recession, the company is well-positioned due to its robust business mix and integrated marketing offering. The article also highlights the company's financial performance, valuation, and future prospects. Additionally, it mentions the upcoming report's focus on PUB's business segments, transformation, competitive dynamics, the Epsilon acquisition, and potential risks. Overall, the article provides an in-depth analysis of Publicis Groupe's strengths and potential in the advertising industry.

title: Bond Funds in the Aftermath of SVB’s Collapse
summary: The article discusses the impact of the banking crisis in March 2023 on fixed-income, open-end bond funds. It highlights how the establishment of the Bank Term Funding Program (BTFP) inadvertently led to net outflows from bond funds, potentially due to the perceived safety of bank deposits. The analysis shows that bond funds experienced persistent outflows for almost three weeks, affecting a wide cross-section of funds. The outflows were more severe for corporate bond funds compared to equity funds, and the crisis coincided with a period of rising interest rates, further impacting bond fund flows. While the outflows may not raise significant financial stability concerns in absolute terms, they could still disrupt illiquid markets. The authors emphasize the interconnectedness of financial intermediation activities and advocate for a more integrated approach to monitoring and regulating both banks and nonbank financial institutions. Nicola Cetorelli and Sarah Zebar from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York authored the post.

title: God Help Us, Let's Try To Understand AI Monosemanticity
summary: The article discusses the challenge of interpreting the inner workings of AI, particularly the complex neural networks. It introduces the concept of "monosemanticity" and the idea that within an AI, there exists a larger AI trying to emerge. The article explores the difficulty in understanding the functioning of AI due to the intricate nature of its neurons and their representation of concepts. It delves into the Anthropic interpretability team's attempt to dissect a simulated AI and the discovery of monosemantic features. The team's findings suggest that simulated neurons are more interpretable than real neurons, paving the way for potential advancements in AI interpretability. The article also highlights the challenges and future prospects of scaling the interpretation of AIs, as well as the implications for understanding human neural reasoning. It concludes by suggesting further reading and potential career opportunities in the field of AI alignment.

title: Making Hay Monday - November 27th, 2023
summary: The article discusses the overcrowding of mega-cap tech stocks and the potential risks associated with it. It highlights the exceptional profits of these elite companies and the impact of the economy on their earnings. The article also touches on the divergence between corporate profits and wages, attributing it to factors like China's inclusion in the WTO and the exceptional profits of mega-cap tech companies. It further discusses the stock performance of Nvidia, emphasizing the challenges of capitalizing on upside breakouts and the potential risks associated with the semiconductor industry. The author advises reducing exposure to the tech sector in investment portfolios.

title: Bond Funds in the Aftermath of SVB’s Collapse
summary: The article discusses the impact of the banking crisis in March 2023 on fixed-income, open-end bond funds. It highlights that these funds experienced net outflows for almost three weeks after the crisis, possibly due to the establishment of the Bank Term Funding Program (BTFP) making bank deposits comparatively safer. The analysis also compares the outflows of corporate bond funds and equity funds, showing a differential impact. Additionally, it examines the effect of interest rates on bond fund holdings, indicating a stronger negative impact in the absence of government intervention. The article concludes by emphasizing the interconnectedness of financial intermediation activities and suggests a more integrated approach to monitoring and regulating such activities. Nicola Cetorelli and Sarah Zebar from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York authored the post.

title: The Nonbank Shadow of Banks
summary:
The article discusses the evolution of nonbank financial institutions (NBFIs) within bank holding companies (BHCs) and their joint evolution over the past fifty years. It explores the relationship between banks and NBFIs, highlighting the increasing role of NBFIs within BHCs and their contribution to assets and operating revenue. The authors argue that the co-evolution of banks and NBFIs suggests a complementary relationship rather than substitution. They also examine the impact of regulatory changes, such as living wills, on the relationship between depository institutions and nonbank activities. The evidence suggests that the number of nonbank subsidiaries under the control of depository institutions has been substantial, and the authors plan to investigate further in a forthcoming paper. Nicola Cetorelli and Saketh Prazad from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York authored the post.

Please note that the article is a detailed analysis of the relationship between banks and nonbank financial institutions within bank holding companies, and their joint evolution over the past fifty years.

title: Presentism and veganism: If I’m wrong, I’m wrong now and forever (crosspost from Substack)
summary: The article advocates for historical 'presentism', which involves assessing past events and actions in the same way as those in the present. The author argues that individuals from the past, such as enslavers, racists, and warmongers, should be viewed in the same light as those in the present. The author rejects the idea of suspending judgment on people in the past based on future societal changes, using the example of veganism to illustrate their point. They emphasize that individuals who were aware of the ethical implications of their actions, such as Calhoun, Jefferson, or Locke, should be held accountable regardless of the prevailing beliefs of their time. The article also acknowledges the limitations of presentism, particularly in historical contexts where societal views were vastly different. The author anticipates that the discussion will likely focus on the merits of veganism and encourages readers to provide alternative examples to support the case for anti-presentism.

title: Commercializing is Viability

It highlights the gap between the idealistic vision of a sustainable world and the practical challenges of creating a successful company. The author emphasizes the complexity of commercializing new chemical products, outlining the intricate process from creating the product to navigating regulatory requirements and market demand. The article stresses the importance of early commercialization trials and the need for founders to gain experience in the commercialization process. It also draws parallels with historical examples, such as the development of polyethylene, to underscore the time and effort required for successful commercialization.

title: For those of you in China exactly one year ago today, I am sure you remember what you did and what went through your mind. Here is my recollection of that fateful day.

The article also reflects on the chaotic aftermath of China's sudden reopening, with shortages of medical supplies and overwhelming healthcare services. The author's relief upon arriving in Hong Kong and the impact of China's former leader Jiang Zemin's death on the country's policies are also mentioned. Overall, the article provides a firsthand account of the challenges and consequences of China's COVID-19 response.

title: 一年前的今天，对于身在中国的人来说，你很难忘记自己身在何处，心中经历了什么。以下是我对2022年 11 月 27 日这一重要日子的个人回忆。
summary: The article discusses the author's experience during a significant day in China, where protests erupted due to a fire incident in Urumqi, Xinjiang. The protests were a culmination of public frustration over continuous lockdown measures. The author, who was leaving Beijing for Hong Kong, observed the events with a mix of excitement and apprehension. The protests ultimately led to pressure on the Chinese leadership, resulting in an early relaxation of the strict "zero-COVID" policies. However, the sudden reopening led to chaos and a surge in respiratory illness cases, causing strain on the healthcare system. Ultimately, it encourages readers to break free from the cycle of delayed gratification and embrace a balanced approach to life.

title: Presentism and veganism: If I’m wrong, I’m wrong now and forever (crosspost from Substack)
summary: The article advocates for historical 'presentism', which involves assessing past events and actions in the same way as those in the present. The author argues that individuals from the past, such as enslavers, racists, and warmongers, should be viewed in the same light as those in the present. The author rejects the idea of suspending judgment on people in the past based on future societal changes, using the example of veganism. They emphasize that individuals who were aware of the harm they were promoting and profiting from, such as Calhoun, Jefferson, or Locke, should be held accountable. The company is expected to generate revenues of $9.8 billion and EBIT of $2.4 billion, reflecting a significant improvement in its cost structure. Airbnb's TTM operating margins are over 3,000 basis points higher than pre-pandemic levels, showcasing operational changes and a narrower strategic focus. title: Americans are angry about immigration

title: Internet Censorship Update: Blocking of murrayhunter.substack.com website
summary: The website murrayhunter.substack.com was found to be blocked by Malaysian ISPs, following a report by the website owner. The blocking was confirmed by Sinar Project and OONI, affecting users of at least 4 ISPs. The blocking involved DNS tampering, redirecting users to MCMC's IP address. Despite no response from MCMC, the website remained inaccessible on the mentioned ISPs. The situation was updated on 24th November, confirming the continued blockage.

title: Johor PKR chapter suggests that teachers who don’t support the government be monitored
summary: The article discusses the call by Johor PKR representative Hayati Abu Nasir to monitor teachers who do not support the government in schools, likening it to oppressive surveillance practices in history. The suggestion is criticized for resembling past regimes' monitoring of citizens and is seen as a step towards a surveillance state, potentially leading to fear, anxiety, and repression in Malaysian schools. The rationale behind the suggestion is deemed political rather than educational. The article warns against the potential negative impact on freedom of expression and thought, drawing parallels to repressive societies like North Korea and highlighting the dangers of potential exploitation and blackmail.

title: The Nonbank Shadow of Banks
summary: The article discusses the evolution of nonbank financial institutions (NBFIs) within bank holding companies (BHCs) and their joint evolution with banks. It presents evidence that NBFIs have become significant contributors to the business model of BHCs, with a steadily increasing share of total BHC assets and operating revenue. The authors argue that the relationship between NBFIs and depository institutions within BHCs may allow the exploitation of synergies, creating benefits for the organization as a whole. The article also explores the impact of living wills on the count of NBFI subsidiaries, suggesting that regulatory changes have influenced the organizational separation between depository institutions and nonbank activities. The authors, Nicola Cetorelli and Saketh Prazad, are affiliated with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The post provides a unique database of the organizational structure of all BHCs since the 1970s to track the joint evolution of banks and nonbanks over the past thirty years.

title: In defence of effective altruism
summary: The article discusses the Effective Altruism movement and its premise of giving money to help poor people, based on consequentialism. It challenges the idea of addressing needs directly and emphasizes the importance of opportunity cost. The article also highlights the potential drawbacks and qualifications of giving money directly, such as the role of family heads in decision-making and the risk of aid theft by corrupt officials. It suggests that sending money may be a more effective approach and raises questions about the effectiveness of other forms of aid. The article also addresses the use of ad hominem arguments and contrasts the movement's principles with examples of corrupt behavior.

title: Interview #80 : Tom Bachrach (PFH Capital)

His initial naive attempt to make money evolved into a full-fledged passion for investing, which he found intellectually invigorating. title: Credit where credit’s due
summary: Central bankers have rapidly increased interest rates this year, despite predictions of a recession. However, the American economy has not faltered, contradicting the pessimistic forecasts. Despite being proven wrong, many still believe a recession is imminent, but evidence suggests otherwise. The economy is still expanding, and there is no sign of a recession.

title: Shannon's Demon
summary: The article discusses Claude Shannon, the inventor of information theory, who also achieved remarkable success as an investor. Shannon's concept of using 0's and 1's for computer communication revolutionized modern technology. He outperformed the majority of mutual funds and demonstrated a unique investment strategy. Shannon's Demon, a concept he introduced, illustrates how a simple change in investment approach can yield positive long-term returns, despite zero expected returns. By rebalancing the portfolio after each bet, even with zero expected return assets, the compounded annual growth rate (CAGR) becomes positive. This concept has significant real-world implications, including evaluating investment strategies, understanding the success of Warren Buffet's buy and hold strategy, and practical applications in portfolio management.

title: Journal: Gratitude, Admiration, and Your Life in 10,000 Days🦃

It highlights the economic challenges faced by Americans, such as inflation, government intervention in key sectors, and foreign intervention, drawing parallels with Argentina's economic struggles. The author advocates for a shift towards radical liberty, emphasizing the need to dissolve the politicized monetary system, depoliticize money and banking, and end Washington's pursuit of a global empire. The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of strong grassroots movements in advocating for liberty and the potential for a freer, safer, and wealthier future.

title: AIER’s Thanksgiving Cost Index Climbs Over 5 Percent from 2022 to 2023
summary: The article discusses the Thanksgiving Cost Index, tracking price changes for specific holiday-related goods and services. The index rose 5.3% from October 2022 to 2023, less than the previous year's 17.8% increase but steeper than 2020-2021 and 2019-2020. The cost of eating at a restaurant also rose by 5.37%. The twenty-year trend shows a 32% increase since October 2019. The American Farm Bureau Federation predicts Thanksgiving dinners to be 4.5% cheaper than last year. Additionally, the article examines secondary Thanksgiving expenses, noting a mix of price increases and decreases. It attributes the expensive holiday season to monetary interventions during the COVID pandemic, indicating slow and limited disinflation. He emphasizes the impact of COVID-related monetary interventions on the Thanksgiving Cost Index and the general price level.

title: Feeling strangely optimistic about Egypt

It suggests that Egypt should focus on attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) in manufacturing to boost exports. The country's strengths include its geographical location, large domestic market, stability, abundant sunlight for solar power, and significant infrastructure investment. However, challenges such as water scarcity, low education levels, corruption, and high foreign debt pose risks to its economic prospects. The government is urged to prioritize FDI and exports, reorient infrastructure spending, increase domestic savings, invest in education, and improve special economic zone (SEZ) policies. Despite the challenges, the article expresses optimism about Egypt's potential for successful industrialization and economic growth.

title: At least five things for your Thanksgiving weekend (#20)

Lastly, it discusses the ongoing debate about income inequality, highlighting the disagreement between different economists and the challenges in measuring income concentration. The article provides insights into these economic issues, offering critical analysis and perspectives on each topic.

title: Car Markets at the End of the Chip Shortage
summary: The article discusses the end of the semiconductor shortage in the US, which had caused a significant impact on vehicle production and consumer prices. The resolution of the chip shortage allowed domestic vehicle production to normalize, but a subsequent strike by United Auto Workers led to a decline in output. However, the swift resolution of the strike is expected to lead to a rebound in output. The article also highlights the recovery of vehicle production in America's major trade partners and the resulting increase in US net real imports of motor vehicles. These supply-side improvements, along with weakening demand due to tighter financial conditions, are putting downward pressure on American vehicle prices.

summary: The article reflects on the Anwar administration's first year, highlighting its continuity with past policies. It then examines Anwar's current policies, indicating a continued emphasis on Islamization, affirmative action, and economic philosophies consistent with his past. The article concludes that Anwar's administration resembles previous governments in substance, despite a different style, and suggests that it has brought stability rather than significant reform.

title: Press Statement: Auditor-General’s Report 2022: Massive losses in public projects reaffirm major need for government accountability
summary: The Auditor-General's Report for 2022 revealed significant losses totaling RM681.71 million from 6 out of 16 performance audits across 14 ministries in Malaysia. The report highlighted failures in meeting project objectives, with 11 projects falling short and only 2 succeeding. The Center to Combat Corruption and Cronyism (C4 Center) called for investigations into potential corruption contributing to these losses and emphasized the need for institutional reforms, including the legislation of a Government Procurement Act and the establishment of an Ombudsman Office. The report also exposed flaws in the public procurement system, lack of transparency, and accountability measures, raising concerns about corruption and mismanagement of public funds. The statement urged the government to prioritize reforms, enhance the Auditor-General's office capacity, introduce a Government Procurement Bill, and intensify efforts to investigate failures and irregular payments to eliminate corruption. The C4 Center emphasized the urgency of these reforms to prevent further wastage and ensure transparency in government projects.

title: Bridge to Nowhere
summary: The article discusses the potential risks associated with mortgage real estate investment trusts (mREITs), focusing on Arbor Realty Trust (NYSE:ABR). Viceroy Research released a report claiming that Arbor's $2.3 billion common equity is worthless due to the company's provision of bridge loans for multifamily apartment complex renovations. The report alleges that soaring interest rates have negatively impacted the economics of these projects, leading to underwater borrowers and inflated collateral values. Arbor's credit quality has deteriorated, with a significant increase in loans labeled as "special mention" or worse. The company's management attributes this deterioration to the natural aging of loans, but the article suggests that it poses a significant problem. The report prompted a deeper evaluation of Arbor's financials to assess Viceroy's claims. The article highlights the concentration of Arbor's loan portfolio in the U.S. sunbelt and the potential risks faced by Arbor equity holders due to poor business execution and rising interest rates.

title: In defence of effective altruism

It concludes by suggesting that sending money may often be the best approach when advocating policies to help the poor. The article also addresses the use of ad hominem arguments and contrasts the movement with a controversial figure in the crypto world.

title: Illustrated Frankenstein - Chapter 21
summary: The article is a passage from Chapter 21 of the novel "Frankenstein" by Mary Shelley. It describes the protagonist's encounter with the magistrate and witnesses who testify about the discovery of a murdered man. The protagonist becomes agitated as the details of the murder remind him of his own brother's death. He is then taken to see the body and experiences extreme distress. Subsequently, he falls ill and is imprisoned, where he reflects on his miserable state. The magistrate shows him kindness, and his father visits him, bringing some relief. The protagonist is eventually acquitted and plans to return to Geneva to protect his loved ones and seek revenge on the murderer. The passage delves into the protagonist's mental anguish, despair, and the torment of his past actions.

title: The Osama Bin Laden “Letter to the American people”
summary: Osama Bin Laden's purported "letter to the American people" was published by Al-Qaeda in 2002, presenting a manifesto against the US political system and foreign policy. The letter, blending Islamic doctrine and political grievances, has resurfaced on social media during the Israel-Hamas conflict, resonating with some groups. It criticizes the US deep state, attacks the control of capital by large companies, and comments on various issues still relevant today. The letter may be used to support antisemitic stands and has been linked to the sentiments of radical organizations like Black Lives Matter. It addresses the US empire, criticizes the administration's policies, and calls for a revolution for freedom. The letter also emphasizes the need to understand historical parallels and advocates for a change in US policies towards Palestine. It concludes with a call to stop aggression and asserts that justice and security offer the best livelihood. The letter is a significant historical document that continues to provoke discussion and reflection.

title: 461: OpenAI Saga, Alibaba, Moats Are Not Static, Ford EV Plans, Microsoft's GPU Capex, Unreal Engine, RAM, and 'No CGI' Lies

The conversation delves into the democratization of AI knowledge, the role of generative AI in healthcare, and the potential for AI to address loneliness. Andrew Ng emphasizes the need for a balanced approach to AI regulation and the importance of open-source software for innovation. The conversation concludes with a focus on the ongoing progress and potential of AI, with a call for collaboration and continued advancement in the field.

This experience leads to insights about human psychology and the tendency to seek emotional gains through impulsive purchases. The author acknowledges the aspiration of rationality but recognizes the deep-seated elements of human psychology that can ensnare us. The article also mentions the reader-supported nature of the publication and encourages subscriptions for access to premium content. title: Buffett Accelerates Gifts to Family Foundations
summary: Warren Buffett converted 1,600 Class A shares of Berkshire Hathaway, valued at $876.2 million, into 2.4 million Class B shares to gift to family foundations. This marks the second consecutive year of supplemental gifts, reflecting his intention to donate over 99% of his wealth to philanthropy. Buffett's children, named as executors of his will and trustees of his charitable trust, will receive over 99% of his wealth, with decisions requiring unanimous consent. The gradual conversion of Class A shares to Class B will change ownership and control of Berkshire Hathaway. Buffett's recent gifts total 383,787,351 Class B shares, worth over $51.8 billion, illustrating the power of compounding and generosity. The article emphasizes the impact of Buffett's gifts and the future of Berkshire Hathaway after his passing.

title: Sharp China: Xi-Biden at APEC; Xi’s Message to the Business Community; Another ‘Dictator’ Comment; Eyes on Taiwan’s Presidential Election
summary: The article is about a week of news from San Francisco, discussing topics such as the US-China relationship, world leaders comparing cars, concessions from the US, PRC commitment on fentanyl, China's preference for Biden or Trump in 2024, achievements from the Biden-Xi meeting, Xi's message to the business community, President Biden's "dictator" assessment, implications after an alliance between minority parties in Taiwan, translators, Xi's reaction to a Warriors jersey, and promising news for panda lovers in the United States.
