Montier highlighted that the US, UK, France, Spain, and Australia are all at danger levels of private sector debt. He also noted that the level of private sector credit, rather than the rate of growth, is the critical factor. Montier expressed concern about the risk of recession, high market valuations, and the concentration of debt by sector. He suggested three routes to protect portfolios: holding cash, using options, and using strategies with a negative correlation to tail risk. Montier discussed the challenges and expenses associated with option protection and highlighted the potential benefits of a quality minus junk strategy. He also emphasized the high valuation of quality stocks and expressed a preference for a value versus growth strategy. Montier concluded by mentioning the significant sectoral exposure of the private equity-owned corporate sector, which could have potential knock-on impacts in the event of a major credit event.

title: Links - 10/16/2023
summary: Warren Buffett, in a 1988 quote, emphasizes the importance of adapting to changing markets. He argues that instead of trying to enter the successor products that are driving your business under, it is better to get out of the declining product or industry. Buffett uses the example of passenger trains being replaced by airplanes, and how the solution was not for train companies to enter the airline business, but rather to exit the passenger business altogether. He also mentions the case of television, which went from being absent in most homes to having multiple sets in almost every home, yet the profitability of U.S. TV manufacturers is likely negative. Buffett's message is that clinging to a dying product or industry is not a wise strategy, and businesses should be willing to adapt and explore new opportunities.

title: Copart Business History
summary: Willis Johnson, the founder of Copart, started his entrepreneurial journey in the junkyard business. He learned the value of hard work and discipline while working on his family's dairy farm and dismantling cars for scrap metal. He eventually focused on selling car parts individually, which allowed him to command higher prices. He also specialized in Chrysler, Dodge, and Plymouth parts, which differentiated him from his competitors. In the 1980s, Johnson purchased BTS Auctions and transformed it into Copart Auctions. He introduced the Percentage Incentive Program (PIP), which allowed insurance companies to split the increase in price from making salvaged cars look nicer. Copart also embraced technology early on, launching an online platform for buyers to bid on cars. The company experienced significant growth and went public in 1994. It continued to expand through acquisitions and the development of a national network of yards. Copart's success can be attributed to its focus on customer needs, operational efficiency, and technological innovation.

title: The Mega Risks and Traditional Energy As A Hedge
summary: The emergence of three mega risks—War, Inflation/Stagflation, and Rich Country Government Debt Burdens—is shaping up to add new dimensions of uncertainty to an already messy energy transition era. Rising tensions in the Middle East following the terrorist attack by Hamas in Israel add a second theatre of conflict to go along with the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war. After a 40-year run of contained inflation and declining interest rates, the 2020s are shaping up to be a different environment. Energy prices are likely to contribute to higher future inflation as both traditional and new energy supply are not on-track to meet global needs. The risk of adverse consequences from continuously rising government debt levels in the United States is increasing. The magnitude of yet-to-be-met energy demand among the other 7 billion people on Earth overwhelmingly points to the need for all forms of energy. Traditional energy sectors may serve as a hedge to the growing mega risks, potentially counter-balancing its recession exposure. New energy technologies have an important role to play in meeting global energy needs, but getting the economics right is more important than an impossibly fast transition.

title: Andrew Bridgen's speech to the British Parliament on excess deaths
summary: In a recent adjournment debate speech in the House of Commons, Andrew Bridgen MP discussed the issue of excess deaths worldwide over the past two years. He highlighted the significant increase in mortality rates during this period, attributing it to various factors such as the COVID-19 pandemic, lockdown measures, and disruptions to healthcare services. Bridgen emphasized the need for a comprehensive analysis of excess deaths to understand the true impact of the pandemic and to inform future policy decisions. He also called for an investigation into the accuracy of COVID-19 death statistics and raised concerns about the potential long-term consequences of delayed medical treatments and missed diagnoses. Bridgen urged the government to prioritize the restoration of normal healthcare services and to address the underlying causes of excess deaths.

title: UBB Amanah: Total Funds Managed RM3B to RM5B. Estimated depositors 30K to 40K...and a Tan Sri.
summary: Lim Lip Eng, a member of the Malaysian Parliament, raised concerns about a Ponzi scheme involving cash trust and preference shares that has been active since 2008. Scammers have been using authorized trust companies, preference share companies, and venture capital companies to deceive people into depositing money and making illegal investments. The scheme not only defrauds people but also helps them evade taxes. Famous individuals, lawyers, celebrities, insurance agents, and bank agents have been promoting this Ponzi scheme. Victims are tricked into signing various contracts, and when the companies are unable to repay them, they realize they are trapped and cannot retrieve their hard-earned money. Some of the companies involved in this scam include UBB Amanah Berhad, ZICO Trust Malaysia Berhad, Infinity Trustee Berhad (now known as Perintis Amanah Berhad), Global Asset Trustee Berhad, Citadel Trustee Berhad, Asia International Trust Berhad, Amanah Warisan Berhad, ACE Holding Berhad, and Pacific Trustees Group International Berhad. Lim Lip Eng has urged the government to take immediate action to protect people from falling victim to these unregulated Ponzi schemes and to impose severe penalties on the scammers involved.

He launched Quercus Fund with a fee structure similar to Warren Buffett's partnerships in the 50s and 60s, with zero management fees and performance fees only above a certain threshold. Milano's ideal investment is an extremely undervalued business with a healthy balance sheet, poised for a significant increase in earnings and with a long runway for reinvestment. title: Age of Invention: How to Steal Technology
summary: John Holker, a skilled cloth manufacturer from Manchester in the early 18th century, was a Catholic and a Jacobite who joined Bonnie Prince Charlie's troops during the Jacobite uprising in 1745. After being captured and imprisoned, Holker escaped and eventually became an industrial spymaster for the French government. His main task was to steal British textile technologies, as Britain was already at the forefront of European technological development in many industries, including textiles, before the Industrial Revolution. Holker set up a network of agents in England and enticed skilled workers to come to France, where he ensured their skills were spread to French workers. The French government provided financial incentives and subsidies to promote the adoption of British techniques. Holker's efforts were successful, and he was promoted to Inspector-General of Manufactures. His son, John Holker Jr., followed in his footsteps as an industrial spy. Holker's career highlights his talent for espionage and his contribution to the transfer of technology between countries during this period.

title: Semiconductor Industry Primer
summary: The global semiconductor sector can be divided into five stages: Instruction Set Architecture (ISA), Chip Design, Fabrication, Equipment & Software, and Packaging & Testing. The ISA stage involves the fundamental "language" that a semiconductor chip uses, with two dominant ISAs being Complex Instruction Set Computer (CISC) and Reduced Instruction Set Computer (RISC). Chip Design involves designing the chip itself, with companies like Apple, Google, and Intel playing a role in this stage. Fabrication is the manufacturing stage, with TSMC, Samsung, and Intel being the major players. Equipment & Software refers to the machines and technology used in the fabrication process, with ASML being the only company capable of producing the necessary equipment. Finally, Packaging & Testing involves packaging the chip and testing it for defects before it is shipped out. This subsector is highly fragmented. The article highlights the strategic importance of the semiconductor sector and how it has become a geopolitical chess piece.

The author explores the implications of this incident, including the vulnerability of global trade routes and the potential for geopolitical tensions. The article also highlights the role of technology in modern shipping and the need for improved infrastructure and contingency plans. Brunet emphasizes the importance of understanding the interconnectedness of the global economy and the potential consequences of disruptions in trade. The article concludes by calling for a reevaluation of our reliance on global supply chains and the need for greater resilience in the face of future challenges.

title: Lessons from History: The Rise and Fall of the Telecom Bubble
summary: The article discusses the similarities and differences between the telecom bubble of the late 1990s and early 2000s and the current boom in artificial intelligence (AI) and infrastructure. The author highlights the parallels in terms of the exponential growth in demand and the belief in scaling to larger networks or neural networks. They also note the high capital intensity of both industries. However, the author emphasizes that there are significant differences, such as the lower leverage in the AI industry compared to the telecom bubble, the lower barrier to entry in AI, and the current rate hike cycle that has prevented excessive speculation. The author also discusses the importance of supply reacting to demand and how supply in the AI industry is likely to eventually overshoot demand. Overall, the article provides insights into the potential risks and dynamics of the current AI and infrastructure boom.

title: Logista: The Distribution Pillar of Imperial Brands
summary: Imperial Brands, a tobacco company, has a majority stake in Logista, a distribution company that moves products across Europe. Logista handles various parts of the value chain, including ordering systems, stock management, transportation, and distribution. It serves a wide range of industries, including food, publications, consumer packaged goods, and pharmaceuticals. Despite challenges such as supply chain disruptions and rising costs, Logista has thrived and reported strong financial performance. The company has also made several acquisitions to expand its operations, including express courier services and specialty long-distance haul services. Logista's operations provide financial benefits to Imperial Brands, including a cash pooling arrangement and a hedge against the decline in traditional tobacco volumes. Logista has a clear path for future growth and plans to use excess funds for further acquisitions. The company has maintained a high payout ratio and has returned a significant amount of capital to shareholders. Overall, Logista demonstrates the continued relevance and value generation of the tobacco industry.

title: On Genome Editing With Fyodor Urnov, A Pioneer
summary: Fyodor Urnov, a professor at UC Berkeley and a pioneer in genome editing, discusses the current state and future potential of CRISPR gene editing technology in a conversation with Eric Topol. Urnov explains that CRISPR has the potential to treat a wide range of diseases, including degenerative diseases, heart disease, sickle cell disease, and cancer. He emphasizes the importance of focusing on severe diseases with high unmet needs and the need for academic and non-profit institutions to step up and develop accelerated ways to build cures for these diseases. Urnov also addresses concerns about off-target effects and the need for further research to ensure the safety and efficacy of CRISPR treatments. He concludes by highlighting the importance of making CRISPR treatments more affordable and accessible to all patients.

title: Covid Nasal Vaccines Get A Boost
summary: Momentum is building towards the development of a nasal COVID-19 vaccine, with promising results from early clinical trials and new funding awards. The rationale for a nasal vaccine is based on the need for population-wide respiratory mucosal immunity to combat the evolving virus and its variants. Experimental studies have shown that nasal vaccines can provide tissue-level mucosal immunity, which is lacking in intramuscular vaccines. Nasal vaccines have been found to induce strong mucosal immunity, lower viral loads, and reduce disease and fatality. They also have the potential to provide variant-proof protection. Two companies, Castlevax and Codagenix, have recently announced the results of their Phase 1 human trials for nasal vaccines and have received funding from the US government to accelerate clinical development. Additionally, researchers at Ohio State University have developed a triple intranasal vaccine against measles, mumps, and COVID-19, which has shown a potent immune response in animal models. While there is still a need for further clinical trials, the development of a safe and effective nasal vaccine could provide durable protection against COVID-19 and help in the fight against the ongoing pandemic.

title: Peter Attia: Our conversation about his hit book OUTLIVE, Medicine 3.0, promoting healthspan, GLP-1 drugs and more
summary: In a conversation with Eric Topol, Peter Attia discusses various topics related to health and medicine. They discuss the concept of Medicine 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0, with Medicine 3.0 focusing on prevention and personalized medicine. Attia emphasizes the importance of health span over lifespan and the need to address chronic diseases. They also discuss the role of nutrition, exercise, and insulin resistance in maintaining health. Attia shares his thoughts on whole-body MRI as a screening tool for cancer, highlighting its high sensitivity but low specificity. He also discusses the potential of GLP-1 drugs for weight loss and the concerns associated with their long-term use. Attia expresses reservations about the drugs' effects on heart rate and muscle mass. Overall, the conversation provides insights into various aspects of health and medicine, emphasizing the importance of personalized approaches and preventive measures.

title: Initial Public Offerings
summary: When a company goes public, it must balance the interests of current shareholders with the goal of raising equity capital. Shareholders want to maximize the valuation of shares, but this carries risks in the long run. Opening for trading below the offering price can be embarrassing and demoralizing. To navigate this, current owners should disclose as much as possible about the business without compromising its competitive position. Warren Buffett's approach to issuing Class B shares in 1996 serves as an example. The players involved in the IPO process have different perspectives based on their incentives. Owners participating in the offering want top dollar, while those planning to exit soon also prefer a high valuation. Owners planning to hold their interest indefinitely want a price that compensates for dilution. The composition of the board of directors determines the dominant owner constituency. Short-term oriented owners may use aggressive accounting methods and non-GAAP metrics to present the business in the best light. Long-term oriented owners prefer candid disclosures. Executive management should have significant stock ownership and stock-based compensation with a multi-year vesting period.

title: Early-stage startup funding is having a moment in Southeast Asia
summary: Early-stage startup funding in Southeast Asia is experiencing a mini boom, with seed and Series A stage activity increasing year-on-year. While later stage deals have declined, there is a growing interest in pre-seed investments, with larger VC firms in the region starting to invest in the bottom of the value chain. The global economic slowdown and the difficulty of landing big investments have pushed fund managers to flock to early-stage deals. Pre-seed investments offer the opportunity for accelerators and angels to pick up stakes in promising startups at low valuations. The failure rate is high for these early investments, but fund managers only need one or two successful startups to generate significant returns. The emergence of more early-stage funding and mentorship resources, managed by senior operators and founders, may change the way accelerators and incubation programs operate in the region. Overall, the increase in early-stage capital is positive for Southeast Asia's startup ecosystem during the current funding winter.

JP Morgan's report on business failures revealed that most failures were outside of management's control, and concentration was found to be both an engine of wealth creation and a potential destroyer of wealth. Research on corporate insider trading found that all insider transactions generated significant abnormal returns, with outlier transactions having higher returns. These findings suggest that corporate insiders exploit their access to non-public information for an unfair advantage in the market.

title: Corporate Insider Trading
summary: Jeff Skilling, the former CEO of Enron, was convicted of conspiracy, insider trading, and securities fraud during the Enron scandal. Skilling and other executives at Enron artificially inflated revenues and hid losses through accounting and corporate fraud. Skilling sold millions of shares before the company's collapse, pocketing millions of dollars. Insider trading by company executives is not uncommon, accounting for 4% of the SEC's actions in 2021. Recent examples include the CEO of Silicon Valley Bank selling shares before the bank collapsed and the Pfizer CEO selling stock on the day the company announced success in clinical trials for its COVID-19 vaccine. Studies suggest that corporate insiders exploit their access to non-public information for unfair market advantage, and the profits generated from insider trading are statistically significant. Detecting illegal insider trading is challenging, but researchers have developed methods to identify potential trading on non-public information. The SEC requires company insiders to report changes in their holdings, and this data is publicly available. Researchers have used time stamps from audit letters to identify if insiders traded on non-public information. Their findings have been presented to the SEC and the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board.

title: British American Tobacco: New FDA Ban on Vuse Alto Menthol Variants Means Little

However, the bans were not a surprise and BAT is challenging them in court, with a good chance of receiving a stay on their implementation. Previous FDA bans have been overturned, and even if the bans were to take effect, Vuse has demonstrated 100% volume retention in a similar ban in California. The key risk remains the FDA's plan to ban menthol cigarettes, which account for 60% of BAT's US cigarette sales. However, previous menthol bans have shown volume retention of 65%+ in the same category and up to 110% including other categories. BAT's low valuation and leadership in vapor products make it a good investment, and the risk from Philip Morris' IQOS menthol products is limited as they are not expected to have a meaningful impact until after 2025. Overall, BAT's shares have a 6.5x P/E and a 14.7% Free Cash Flow Yield, making them an attractive investment.

Investment Banking fees remain below pre-COVID levels, but Sales & Trading revenues have increased. Non-Interest Expenses have continued to decrease, and credit costs for the year are comparable to pre-COVID levels. BAC is already over-capitalized, so the impact of Basel III Endgame rules, which will raise equity capital requirements by 20%, will be less significant. With a Price/Tangible Book Value of 1.15x, BAC shares have a normalized P/E of 8.5x. The dividend yield is 3.5%, and forecasts indicate a total return of 91% by the end of 2026. The investment case for BAC is based on its ability to maintain a low-teens long-term ROTCE on a growing capital base.

title: Back to the Future in Venture Capital: Small is Beautiful
summary: The cost of capital is increasing as baby boomers retire and invest in more conservative assets, leading to markdowns in the private tech market. Startup costs have significantly decreased due to SaaS tools, cloud services, and new distribution platforms, allowing founders to build products with as little as $50-100k. This shift in startup costs has implications for the VC industry, with a move towards bootstrapping and profitability becoming more popular. The VC industry is expected to become more barbell-shaped, with big funds on one end and small, specialized funds on the other. The middle ground will struggle to survive. The restructuring of the VC industry will also lead to a consolidation into three distinct segments: traditional artisanal approach, specialization in B2B SaaS startups, and a shift towards private equity-like investments. Small funds are expected to thrive in this new landscape. The dilution of seed investors' returns in later funding rounds highlights the importance of building a profitable business early on. Overall, this is an exciting time for startups and venture capital as a new Renaissance emerges in Silicon Valley.

title: On Real Rates
summary: US real rates have reached their highest level in 15 years, and understanding why is crucial for those following the economy and capital markets. Real rates are the yield paid on government bonds after inflation is deducted. Currently, the US is experiencing both strong economic growth and a high government budget deficit, leading to an increase in Treasury bond issuance. The main drivers of real rates are economic growth, which is influenced by an expanding labor force and improving productivity. Demographics pose a headwind for real growth, as the long-term trend is down, but there is still a large reservoir of employable people outside the labor force. Productivity is typically low during inflationary periods, but the potential impact of AI could provide a boost from 2025 onwards. The high levels of private sector debt following the Great Financial Crisis drove real rates below zero, but currently, large parts of the US economy have no leverage issue. Overall, the current economic context suggests that real rates are too high, and a significant downside move in equities may be on the horizon.

title: Risk of Ruin
summary: Victor Haghani conducted a study on how finance people manage risk by creating a game where participants bet on the outcome of a weighted coin flip. Despite the clear edge in the game, few players were able to maximize their winnings. Haghani found that players often over-bet, under-bet, and bet on tails, indicating a lack of understanding of position sizing. Position sizing is critical in portfolio management, as correctly sizing picks is more important than identifying good investments. Haghani's experiment highlights the importance of understanding risk and position sizing in finance and gambling. Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of crypto exchange FTX, also had a skewed risk perception, as he believed in going big even if it meant a high chance of going bust. However, this approach is not sustainable in the long run. Bankman-Fried's miscalibrated risk engine led him astray, and his risk preferences made it likely that he would go bust quickly. Overall, understanding risk and position sizing is crucial for success in finance and gambling.

title: Bad Office

Built in 1916, it initially attracted tenants easily but changed ownership multiple times. In 2022, the current owner, RXR Realty, stopped making loan payments to Aareal Bank and went into default. The bank has hired Jones Lang LaSalle to sell the loan at a discount, offering investors an opportunity for capital appreciation. The building's occupancy has dropped to 58% due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, and attempts to attract tenants with discounted rents have been unsuccessful. Repurposing the building for residential use would lower its value significantly. Aareal Bank, with its experience in the real estate industry, has increased its loan loss provisions to absorb the financial hit from 61 Broadway. The bank remains optimistic, recognizing the cyclical nature of the real estate business.

title: 💩Is Big Lots Inc. ($BIG) in BIG Trouble?💩
summary: Big Lots Inc., an Ohio-based retail company, has been experiencing significant declines in sales and comparable sales. The COVID-19 pandemic initially benefited the company as people stocked up on essential items and purchased furniture while in quarantine. However, the company's financial situation has worsened, with declining sales, increased SG&A expenses, and decreasing gross margins due to higher freight costs and inflationary pressures. Despite efforts to improve its balance sheet in FY'20, the company's total debt has skyrocketed to $504.4 million by the end of 2Q'23. To address its liquidity issues, Big Lots has engaged in sale-leaseback transactions, with the latest involving its distribution center in California and 22 store locations, generating net proceeds of approximately $294 million. The company plans to use the proceeds to pay off its debt. However, with limited remaining owned stores and distribution centers, the company may need to explore other options, such as operational improvements or equity dilution, to secure liquidity.

title: 💥New Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Filing - DirectBuy Home Improvement Inc. (d/b/a Z Gallerie)(w/Case Roster)💥
summary: Z Gallerie, a specialty retailer focused on customizable home décor and furnishings, has filed for its third Chapter 11 bankruptcy in the last 14 years. The company, which has 21 remaining retail stores in nine states, has been struggling with underperforming brick-and-mortar stores and adverse macroeconomic trends, including the impact of COVID-19 on the retail industry. Z Gallerie's eCommerce business, which accounted for over 50% of sales in 2022, has not been enough to offset the decline in physical store sales. The company plans to pursue a going concern sale process, with a third-party liquidator and the investment banking firm Stump & Company leading the sale. CSC Generation Holdings, which already owns the DirectBuy business, acquired Z Gallerie out of bankruptcy in 2019 and will provide a $2.2 million debtor-in-possession credit facility to fund the sale process. General unsecured creditors are unlikely to receive any funds due to the extent of the pre-petition secured debt. The first day hearing for the bankruptcy case is scheduled for later today.

title: Problems at LifeStance Health (LFST)
summary: LifeStance Health, a mental health care company, is facing allegations of overbilling, fraudulent billing, and unfair business practices. The Bear Cave, through Freedom of Information Act requests, has uncovered complaints that accuse LifeStance of scheduling therapy appointments without patients' knowledge to incur cancellation and no-show fees, adding unearned billing codes to patient bills, and sending bills to people who have never used their services. The company has also experienced high executive turnover and has a Compliance Committee with concerning oversight. The Better Business Bureau has given LifeStance an F rating and issued an alert about complaints regarding billing issues. State regulators have also received complaints, with one consumer alleging that the company has been involved in fraud and regularly signs patients up for unwanted appointments to boost fee revenue. A former LifeStance employee raised similar concerns about erroneous billing and scheduling visits that were not made. Some customers have been charged cancellation fees for appointments that LifeStance cancels. The allegations raise questions about whether LifeStance is a legitimate therapy franchise or an illegal billing operation.

title: CUTTING THROUGH THE MACRO BABBLE - ADDENDUM
summary: The recent Hamas attack on Israel has caused geopolitical uncertainty, leading to a 4% rally in oil prices. However, contrary to expectations, the VIX (Volatility Index) did not spike, indicating a lack of fear in the market.

title: ANALYSING BLACKSTONE
summary: Private equity firm Blackstone has seen continued growth in assets under management (AUM), leading some to consider it a good investment. However, the theory that rising interest rates would negatively impact private equity seems to be playing out, as publicly reported commitments to private equity have fallen significantly. Despite this, Blackstone recently closed a $30 billion fund, suggesting a lag in money flows. It is important to note that there is a difference between total AUM and fee-earning AUM, with real estate being a significant portion of the latter. Blackstone has been aggressively pursuing the acquisition of listed real estate investment trusts (REITs) and making them private, allowing them to charge performance fees. However, the performance of listed apartment REITs and slowing flows to the private equity sector may put financial pressure on Blackstone's permanent capital structures. Despite rising interest rates, the stability of collateral values, such as rising US house prices, has helped support Blackstone's AUM. However, a short position on Blackstone may be advisable if inflation and interest rates continue to rise or collateral values start to fall.

title: JUNK JUNK FOOD?
summary: McDonald's, a fast food chain, represents pro-capital policies where the risk is shifted to franchisees while the franchisor collects a royalty. The author had previously shorted McDonald's but closed the position before it experienced a 15% fall. The question now is whether this is just a temporary dip or the start of a larger downward trend.

title: THINKING ABOUT PORTFOLIO CONSTRUCTION
summary: The author of the article sees an opportunity for a fund based on the belief that politics is moving towards being pro-labour and away from pro-capital. This leads to a bullish outlook on wages and real assets, and a bearish outlook on financial assets. The author suggests going long on gold (GLD) and short on long-dated treasuries (TLT) as a way to express this view. The author also suggests going long on high-yield bonds (HYG) and short on TLT for those who don't like the negative carry of the GLD/TLT idea. In a pro-labour world, regulations and tariffs are necessary to protect domestic wages, making devaluing the currency unnecessary. This means that foreigners are no longer the main buyers of treasuries, and locals are buying them instead. The author notes that the S&P 500 has held up well against gold, but a short portfolio of bond proxies and businesses that don't work at interest rates above 7% could be profitable.

title: Emerging Markets Monitor - October 10
summary: Israel is preparing for a ground war in Gaza as tensions escalate in the region. Israeli airstrikes have caused significant damage in Gaza, and there are fears that the conflict could spread to other countries in the Middle East. The global economic recovery remains slow, with regional divergences becoming more pronounced. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicts a decline in global growth and inflation, particularly in advanced economies. China's largest property developer, Country Garden, has warned of a potential default on its international debts, adding to concerns about the country's property sector. Meanwhile, Huawei is turning to the Middle East to promote its 5G technology as it faces increasing pressure in Europe. The company is working on 5.5G technology to meet the growing demand for high-speed networks. In Malaysia, UAE's Masdar has committed $8 billion to develop renewable energy projects, including solar power plants and wind farms, by 2035.

title: Emerging Markets Monitor - October 19
summary: Emerging markets are facing pressure due to soaring oil prices and escalating conflict in the Middle East. Stock markets have fallen, with the Mexican peso experiencing significant losses. Dollar bonds issued by Middle Eastern sovereigns have also performed poorly. Oil prices have surged above $90 per barrel as Iran calls for an embargo against Israel, leading to concerns about further escalation of the conflict. Despite this, some Asian assets briefly rallied after positive Chinese growth data, but the gains were short-lived. India is seen as the next big emerging market growth story, with its strong GDP growth and stock market performance. The country's growth is attributed to improvements in basic infrastructure and favorable demographics. India's working-age population is expected to rise, offsetting issues with female labor force participation and underemployment. Transsion, a Chinese smartphone maker, is experiencing growth and increased market share in emerging markets, particularly Africa. It is the only top-five smartphone vendor to gain market share in the third quarter. South Korea is projected to become the world's seventh-largest economy by 2040, with a focus on high-tech industries. The EU is pushing for a world-first deal to phase out CO2-emitting fossil fuels at the upcoming COP28 climate summit.

title: Spilled Milk
summary: Chevron's plans to recycle plastic waste by transforming it into jet fuel have been met with backlash from environmental groups. The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) approved Chevron's proposal, but the decision has sparked criticism and accusations of toxic air pollution and cancer risks. The EPA's approval was based on a worst-case scenario assessment that assumed extreme and unrealistic conditions. In reality, the risks associated with Chevron's proposed fuel were found to be minimal. The environmental groups' claims have been debunked, but the damage has already been done, with Chevron facing defamation and a lawsuit. The article highlights the challenges faced by companies in the fossil fuel industry when attempting to address plastic waste and the tactics used by environmentalists to hinder their efforts.

title: Minority Report
summary: The 118th US Congress has a slim majority, with Republicans holding a razor-thin edge. Former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy was ousted from his position after a motion to remove him was brought by a conservative member and every Democrat voted against him. McCarthy's removal came after House conservatives feared he had cut a side deal with President Biden on Ukraine funding. The war in Ukraine is not going well, and conservative opposition to sending more military assistance is growing. This poses a challenge for the Biden administration as it heads into an election year. The situation in the Middle East, with the assault by Hamas on Israel, further complicates matters. Funding for Ukraine is running dry, and the pressure on the situation is increasing. The Biden administration is considering linking Ukraine funding to aid for Israel in an attempt to increase the chances of Congress approving aid to Kyiv. However, the situation remains fluid, and much depends on how quickly Republicans can settle on a new speaker and how strongly conservatives oppose Ukraine. Meanwhile, Russian President Putin has blamed the US for the violence in Israel and warned of conflict expansion. In the midst of these events, a natural gas pipeline connecting Finland to Estonia has been severely damaged, possibly due to sabotage. The situation raises questions about Putin's intentions and the potential for further escalation.

title: False Utopia
summary: Uruguay's transition to renewable energy is often hailed as a success story, with the country reportedly running on 98% renewable electricity. However, a closer look reveals that Uruguay still relies on fossil fuels during periods of drought and that hydroelectric dams play a significant role in its renewable energy mix. The country's small population and relatively low GDP per capita also make its situation less applicable to larger, wealthier nations. Additionally, Uruguay's high consumption of beef contributes significantly to its carbon footprint. The article argues that Uruguay's experience highlights the limitations and challenges of achieving a fully renewable electricity grid, including the need for backup power and the environmental impact of large-scale dams. It suggests that the country's story should be viewed with nuance and caution, rather than as a blueprint for other nations.

title: One Thing: 10/10/23
summary: The Kowloon Walled City was a densely populated, lawless enclave in Hong Kong that existed from the 1940s until its demolition in 1994. Originally a military fort, it became a haven for refugees and squatters, eventually growing into a self-contained city with its own economy and social structure. The Walled City was notorious for its cramped living conditions, lack of sanitation, and rampant crime. However, it also had a vibrant community and a unique architectural style, with buildings stacked on top of each other and interconnected by a maze of narrow alleyways. Despite its reputation, the Walled City had a surprisingly low crime rate and a strong sense of community. The demolition of the Walled City was met with mixed reactions, with some residents mourning the loss of their homes and others relieved to escape the squalor. Today, the site of the Walled City has been transformed into a park, but its legacy lives on as a symbol of urban chaos and resilience.

title: Illustrated Frankenstein - Chapter 15
summary: The creature in Mary Shelley's Frankenstein reflects on the impact of reading books on his intellectual development. He finds delight and fascination in the stories of Paradise Lost, Plutarch's Lives, and The Sorrows of Werter. These books introduce him to new ideas and emotions, and he relates to the characters and their experiences. However, the creature also becomes increasingly aware of his own isolation and monstrous appearance. He longs for companionship and hopes that the cottagers he observes will accept and understand him. Eventually, he decides to reveal himself to the blind old man in the cottage, hoping to gain his sympathy and support. However, when the old man's family discovers the creature, they react with horror and violence. The creature is devastated and flees back to his hovel, feeling rejected and alone once again.

title: One Thing: 10/13/23
summary: The Last Bookstore, located in Los Angeles, is a popular destination for book lovers. The store is known for its unique and creative displays, including book sculptures and a tunnel made entirely of books. It also offers a wide selection of new and used books, as well as vinyl records and artwork. The Last Bookstore hosts various events, such as book signings and live music performances, to engage with the community. The store has become a cultural landmark and a symbol of the enduring love for physical books in the digital age. Despite the challenges faced by brick-and-mortar bookstores, The Last Bookstore has managed to thrive and attract visitors from all over the world.

title: Digital Detox: A Guide to Disconnecting for Mental Wellness
summary: The article discusses the importance of finding balance in our lives and reclaiming a sense of well-being in the digital age. Excessive screen time can lead to increased stress levels, disrupted sleep patterns, and a decline in focus. To address this, the article suggests creating a personalized digital detox plan, setting clear intentions and goals for tech-free periods. Engaging in offline activities such as reading, spending time in nature, and pursuing hobbies can help reconnect with oneself and the world. It is also important to cultivate a mindful and healthy relationship with technology by setting boundaries for screen time and practicing digital minimalism. Prioritizing real connections over virtual ones and nurturing meaningful relationships is crucial for a balanced life. Reclaiming balance is an ongoing practice that requires regular assessment and adjustments. The goal is to find a harmonious coexistence with technology and nurture overall well-being.

title: One Thing: 10/17/23
summary: The article at secondhandsongs.com is a database of cover songs, providing information about the original songs and the artists who covered them. The website allows users to search for specific songs or artists and provides details such as the original release date, the songwriter, and the different versions of the song that have been recorded. Users can also contribute to the database by submitting new cover versions or correcting existing information. The website aims to be a comprehensive resource for music lovers and researchers who are interested in exploring the history and evolution of popular songs.

title: Illustrated Frankenstein - Chapter 16
summary: The creature, filled with rage and revenge, destroys the cottage and its inhabitants. He wanders in the woods, contemplating his situation and planning his next move. He decides to return to the cottage and win over the old man. However, when he arrives, he finds the cottage abandoned and learns from two countrymen that the family has left due to the creature's actions. Filled with despair and anger, the creature sets the cottage on fire and flees into the woods. He continues his journey, enduring suffering and seeking revenge against mankind. Eventually, he arrives in Geneva and encounters a young boy. The creature tries to befriend the boy, but the boy reacts with fear and calls him a monster. In a fit of rage, the creature kills the boy. Overwhelmed by his actions, the creature seeks solace in a barn and encounters a young woman. He contemplates waking her and making her suffer for the pain he has endured, but ultimately decides to leave her unharmed. The creature then wanders the mountains, longing for companionship and demanding that his creator, Victor Frankenstein, create a mate for him.

title: One Thing: 10/20/23
summary: Marc Andreessen, co-founder of venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, has published a manifesto on Substack titled "The Techno-Optimist Manifesto." In the manifesto, Andreessen argues that human progress has been slow for most of our existence, but has accelerated dramatically in recent centuries due to technological advancements. He highlights the transformative power of technology in improving living standards, increasing life expectancy, and reducing poverty. Andreessen also discusses the potential of emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, biotechnology, and space exploration to further drive progress and solve pressing global challenges. He emphasizes the importance of embracing and investing in technology to continue this positive trajectory. The manifesto serves as a call to action for individuals, governments, and societies to adopt a techno-optimistic mindset and actively support innovation and technological development.

title: The Stock Market Sits On The Edge Of The End Of The World
summary: The article discusses the current state of the world, highlighting the unprecedented combination of geopolitical volatility and flawed monetary policy, along with domestic division. The author argues that this unique situation will lead to increased volatility in the financial markets. They point out that interest rates are currently at their highest level with the largest amount of debt outstanding in history. The article also mentions the artificial inflation of the market through passive ETF investments, COVID liquidity, and the weaponization of the options market. The author believes that the market is on the verge of a significant downturn due to these factors. Additionally, the article discusses the geopolitical headwinds, such as Russia and China forming a consortium to do business outside the Western banking system, and conflicts in Ukraine and the Middle East. The author concludes by expressing their belief in the value of precious metals and gold miners as a safe investment in these uncertain times.

title: Quick Market Update For Subscribers: 10/13/2023
summary: Sorry, but I can't generate a summary without the article.

title: Financial Free Speech
summary: The article emphasizes the importance of free speech and open discussion in the fields of economics and finance. The author criticizes the mainstream narrative and advocates for the Austrian school of economics, which emphasizes balanced budgets and productive economies. The author also highlights the suppression of free speech during the COVID-19 pandemic and warns that similar actions could be taken in the financial world. The article suggests that the current monetary policies and debt levels could lead to a catastrophic economic slowdown. The author urges readers to pay attention to the growing importance of financial free speech and encourages them to voice their opinions.

title: Global Debt At Record Levels and Rates Are "Going A Lot Higher": Peter Schiff
summary: Global debt has reached a record high of $397 trillion in the first half of 2023, according to the Institute of International Finance (IIF). This increase in debt comes despite tightening credit conditions and is a cause for concern as artificially low interest rates are no longer sustainable. Developed nations, including Japan, the US, Britain, and France, accounted for about 80% of the new global debt, while emerging markets such as China, Brazil, and India also saw significant increases. The IIF warns that as interest rates rise and debt levels increase, domestic debt strains will also rise. The US government alone is over $33 trillion in debt, and interest payments on the debt now match national defense spending. The global economy, which has relied on easy money and low interest rates, is now facing the challenge of higher rates that could potentially break the borrow-and-spend economy. The CPI may show a cooling of inflation, but rising prices are still a concern for Americans. Peter Schiff, an economist, argues that the government is not being honest about inflation, and people are struggling with higher costs of living. To protect themselves, Schiff suggests investing in assets such as gold and silver and divesting from the US dollar.

title: No, We Cannot Afford to Fund Yet Another War
summary: President Joe Biden and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen have claimed that the United States can afford to fund wars in both Israel and Ukraine. However, this claim is not true, as it fails to consider the military goals and the potential costs of these conflicts. In the case of Israel, the goal is not just to prevent Hamas attacks, but to overwhelmingly defeat the movement and kill or capture its leadership. This could be a costly and difficult task, as Hamas has hidden resources and uses an unmapped tunnel system. Similarly, Ukraine's goal is to drive Russian forces out of occupied territories, but the campaign has resulted in heavy casualties and equipment losses without significant territorial gains. Funding these wars would place a heavy financial burden on the American people, who are already facing economic challenges such as dwindling savings, high inflation, and record-high debt. The current monetary system may create the illusion that the government can solve global problems without raising taxes, but in reality, the cost is borne by the public through inflation.

title: Back to Our Targets
summary: Federal Reserve officials are signaling that they are pleased with the current state of inflation and are less likely to raise interest rates again, despite inflation data remaining above the Fed's target. Earnings season has begun, with JP Morgan and Wells Fargo reporting strong consumer spending driven by affluent consumers. However, office portfolios are experiencing weakness. The Fed believes that they are close to the peak of the tightening cycle and rising long-term interest rates will help in managing inflation. Consumer spending remains strong, with growth rates back to pre-pandemic levels, but there are concerns about the lower FICO consumers and geopolitical tensions impacting energy and food markets, global trade, and geopolitical relationships.

title: Castles Crumble in the Middle East
summary: The recent Hamas attack on Israel has exposed the crumbling US strategy in the Middle East, which aimed to encourage diplomatic and business ties between Arab states and Israel while supporting the Sisi regime in Egypt. The article highlights the historical context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, with Israel ruling over a large Palestinian population in the West Bank, Gaza Strip, and within Israel itself. The US had been focused on building Israel's diplomatic bridges and diverting attention away from the Palestinian cause, but Hamas' actions have brought the issue back to the forefront. The article argues that blaming Iranian support for Hamas misses the point of the deep-rooted Palestinian grievances. China's failure to criticize Hamas has shocked the West, but other parts of the world may have a better understanding of the conflict's history. The renewed US focus on the Middle East could divert attention and resources from other global issues. Ultimately, the article questions whether Israel can sustain its control over a large Palestinian population in the long term.

title: Hamas vs. Israel: Regional Geopolitical Maze
summary: The conflict between Hamas and Israel, which has resulted in over 1,100 deaths, is causing concerns of a wider regional conflagration. The conflict is the deadliest and most sophisticated since the Yom Kippur War 50 years ago and is shaking the entire Middle East. It is also impacting the Biden administration's plans to counter Chinese and Russian influence in the region. The US has been a key supporter of Israel, providing annual aid of $3.3 billion, making it the largest recipient of US aid since World War II. However, this aid is now causing condemnation of both Washington and Jerusalem in Middle Eastern capitals. The recent diplomatic forays of China and Russia into the region, particularly their success in normalizing Iran-Saudi and Saudi-Syria ties, have prompted the US to seek normalization between Saudi Arabia and Israel through the Abraham Accords. However, the Saudis have been difficult to bargain with, and the conflict between Hamas and Israel has further complicated the situation. The conflict is also benefiting Iran, as it pushes Saudi Arabia away from normalization. If the war continues and results in heavy casualties among Palestinians, it will shelve the Saudi-Israel deal and affect Washington's plans to reshape the Middle East.

title: Philippines’ Paralysis on Human Rights Issues
summary: The article discusses the efforts of Benjamin Abalos, the interior secretary of the Marcos administration in the Philippines, to clean up the Philippine National Police (PNP) by requesting courtesy resignations from officers. However, over 900 officers out of the 228,000-strong PNP resisted this request. Abalos's goal was to remove corrupt and ineffective officers from the force, but the resistance from these officers highlights the challenges in reforming the police force. The article does not provide further details on the reasons for the officers' resistance or the specific actions taken by Abalos to address the issue.

title: Indonesia Pays For The Rush to Nickel Exploitation
summary: Indonesia is facing challenges in its pursuit of downstream production of its resource wealth, including environmental degradation and depleting resources. The country has granted land concessions for nickel mining, which has reached over a million.

title: India and Pakistan Square Off in World Cup Cricket
summary: India and Pakistan are set to play their inaugural match in the cricket World Cup, igniting one of the world's most intense sports rivalries. The off-field tensions between the two nations, which have a history of conflict and wars, add to the intensity of the match. Despite the political divisions, the cultural similarities between the two countries, including religion, food, customs, music, and movies, unite them. Cricket is a particularly unifying factor, with both Indian and Pakistani fans showing support for each other's teams. The match is expected to draw a massive audience, with half a billion people watching online and the world's largest cricket stadium, Narendra Modi stadium in Ahmedabad, packed to capacity. The demand for tickets and accommodations has skyrocketed, with fans even checking into hospitals near the stadium due to the lack of available hotels. The match holds great significance for both nations, and for the next 24 hours, it will be the center of attention for India and Pakistan.

title: Chinese Renegades Operate Massive Scams in Outlaw Border Zones
summary: Investigations have revealed that renegade Chinese individuals are using Myanmar, Laos, Cambodia, and the Philippines as a base for illegal offshore betting, cyber scams, and sex work industries. These activities are disguised as Belt and Road enterprises. These countries, which are among Asia's poorest nations with weak governance, are being exploited by these individuals. The investigators from various agencies have uncovered this illicit operation, highlighting the need for stronger regulation and enforcement in these countries.

title: BOOK REVIEW: The Sister (The Extraordinary Story of Kim Yo Jong, The Most Powerful Woman in North Korea)
summary: Living in Seoul, near the North Korean border, can be unnerving due to the threat of nuclear bombs and intercontinental missiles. However, it is unclear how much South Koreans and the rest of the world truly understand the danger posed by North Korea.

title: Former FTX Boss’s Massive Bribes to Chinese Officials bigger than expected
summary: A former girlfriend of Samuel Bankman-Fried, the founder of a struggling cryptocurrency exchange, has testified in a New York courtroom that the exchange paid $150 million in bribes to unnamed Chinese officials to unfreeze $1 billion in assets. The testimony has sparked a new manhunt in China.

title: Ecclestone Plea Reawakens Singapore Probe Charges
summary: Bernie Ecclestone, the 92-year-old Formula 1 racing empresario, has admitted guilt on fraud charges filed by British tax authorities. This admission brings attention to the ongoing corruption probe against Singapore's currently-suspended Transport Minister S Iswaran and a prominent hotelier.

title: Way Open for Jokowi's Son in Indonesia’s Vice-Presidential Race
summary: The Constitutional Court of Indonesia has made a decision allowing presidential and vice presidential candidates under the age of 40 to run in the upcoming general election. This decision is seen as a signal that President Joko Widodo's oldest son, Gibran Rakabuming Raka, will be a running mate, potentially establishing a family dynasty. The relationship between President Widodo and his party, the Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle (PDIP), is unclear following his support for Defense Minister Prabowo Subianto, who ran against Widodo in previous elections. The court's decision has been criticized for favoring Gibran and is seen as an indication of political interests influencing election regulations. With the approaching registration period for the general election, tensions are rising, and there are reports of a breakdown in relations between Widodo and the PDIP. Analysts believe that Widodo's support for Prabowo is aimed at securing his political future and protecting his legacy. If rumors of Gibran accompanying Prabowo come true, the PDIP is expected to double its efforts to defeat them in the election.

title: Peril for Taiwan in Cloud of Crises
summary: The article discusses how the Ukraine war has been overshadowed by other events in recent weeks, such as the conflict between Azerbaijan and Armenia in Nagorno-Karabakh and the flight of refugees from Ethiopia's Tigray region. The author compares this to how the Covid-19 pandemic pushed the Hong Kong uprising against Chinese rule out of the news headlines in 2020. The Ukraine war, which has been ongoing for two years, has been a major global issue, but it has now been displaced by other conflicts and crises.

title: Australia’s Bid to Join Asean a Non-Starter
summary: Canberra, the capital city of Australia, is reportedly considering joining the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). Graeme Dobell, a senior fellow at the Australian Strategic Policy Institute, has argued that Australia's partnership with ASEAN would be significant and could potentially change the dynamics of the organization. However, there are conflicting reports on whether Australia is actively pursuing membership or if it is simply exploring the idea. If Australia were to join ASEAN, it would have implications for both Australia and the ASEAN member countries, as it would alter the balance of power and potentially bring about new opportunities for cooperation and collaboration.

title: China Rebrands BRI Amid Global Chaos
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) has gained momentum and global support, contrasting with the ongoing conflicts in the Middle East and Ukraine. The BRI forum, attended by representatives from 130 countries, has showcased China's alternative approach to conflict resolution and economic development. China has made crucial modifications to the BRI, shifting its focus towards services and the digital world. This includes an emphasis on e-commerce, investment protection treaties, standardized trade rules, and green development. The rebranding of the BRI aims to address Western criticism and present China as a responsible economic player. China's openness to foreign investment and removal of restrictions further positions it as an attractive partner for global corporations and governments. In contrast, Washington-supported plans like the India-Middle East-Europe Economic Corridor (IMEC) pale in comparison to the renewed BRI. Ongoing conflicts and Washington's uncritical support for Israel may also impact the viability of these plans. China's revival of the BRI comes at an opportune time for Beijing, while posing challenges for Washington.

title: Reduced BRI Expected to Offer Less Money
summary: China is expected to tighten its funding for Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) projects in the coming years, despite President Xi Jinping's promise to maintain funding at the recent Belt and Road Forum. Analysts predict that China will focus on quality over quantity and prioritize projects that are economically viable and have a positive impact on local communities. This shift in approach is driven by concerns over debt sustainability and the need to address criticism of the BRI's environmental and social impact. China is also likely to increase its scrutiny of potential borrowers and prioritize countries with stable political environments and strong governance. The tightening of funding is expected to affect countries that have already received significant BRI investments, as well as those seeking future funding. However, China will continue to support projects that align with its strategic interests, such as infrastructure development and connectivity initiatives.

title: Prof. Donal O’Neill R.I.P
summary: Donal O'Neill, a respected economist and colleague in Maynooth University's Economics Department, has passed away at the age of 56 after a brief illness. He was known for his contributions to the field of labor economics and inequality, as well as his interest in econometric methodology. Donal published in prestigious journals and served as president of the Irish Economic Association. He was also a dedicated teacher and a beloved colleague. His work was driven by a genuine passion for economics and its potential for positive impact. Donal was remembered as a kind and decent person. Our condolences go out to his family and friends, especially his wife, Olive Sweetman, who is also a member of the Economics Department at Maynooth University.

title: Novavax is here!
summary: Novavax, a small company based in Maryland, has received FDA approval for its updated Covid-19 vaccine. Unlike the mRNA vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna, Novavax's vaccine contains a coronavirus protein that stimulates the immune system. The company has found a way to produce the vaccine using moth cells, allowing for faster manufacturing. The Novavax vaccine has been shown to provide 50% protection against symptomatic disease in fully vaccinated individuals, according to an Italian study. It is available for anyone 12 years and older, including those who have previously received the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines. Distribution of the vaccine will take time, but it will eventually be available at 13,000 stores. There is some evidence that mixing the Novavax vaccine with an mRNA vaccine may be immunologically better, but more research is needed. Novavax has also been found to have fewer side effects compared to mRNA vaccines.

title: State of Affairs: Oct 12
summary: The official start of the respiratory season has begun in the United States, with influenza-like illnesses (ILI) starting to increase but still below epidemic levels. COVID-19 metrics, including wastewater, emergency department visits, and hospitalizations, are declining, following the usual seasonal trend. Hospitalizations for COVID-19 are lower than in previous years due to population-level immunity. The Omicron variant is expected to drive the winter surge, with the BA.2.86 variant showing a growth advantage and FLiP mutations gaining ground. Influenza levels are very low, with one strain, Yamagata influenza B, going extinct due to COVID-19 measures. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is picking up, particularly in the South, signaling the start of the RSV season. Excess mortality is above pre-pandemic levels. Vaccination rates for COVID-19 and flu are still uncertain, with 2% of the eligible population estimated to have received their fall COVID-19 vaccine. It is recommended to get vaccinated before Halloween and to wear masks when ILI levels reach epidemic levels.

title: Social media, terrorist attacks, war, and vicarious trauma
summary: Vicarious trauma, the psychological impact of second-hand exposure to traumatic events, can have long-lasting effects on mental health. The extent of suffering depends on the dose of exposure and socio-demographic factors. Media exposure, especially through social media and television, can worsen the impact of traumatic events. Studies have shown that heavy social media use after such events can lead to an excess mental health service burden. Certain socio-demographic groups, such as those who share a social identity with the victims or have experienced pre-event trauma, are at higher risk of experiencing vicarious trauma. To reduce the impact of vicarious trauma, individuals can turn off auto-play videos on social media, take breaks from social media, pay attention to their emotions, seek social support, talk to someone they trust, find ways to feel useful, and monitor children's exposure to media. It is important to recognize the collective trauma caused by witnessing terrorist attacks and war and to seek support when feeling overwhelmed.

title: My utter failure to write about the public health implications of war
summary: The author of the article discusses the difficulty of accurately describing the complex humanitarian crisis unfolding due to Hamas's attacks and counterattacks. They express their struggle to find the right words to convey the extent of the public health crisis and the suffering caused by the conflict. The author highlights the challenges of balancing nuance and emotions while honoring the dead and the suffering. They question how words can capture the loss of life, the brutal terror from Hamas, the inhumane living conditions, and the ongoing suffering for future generations. The author emphasizes that everyone is losing in this conflict, and what is needed is listening, connecting, processing, and finding glimmers of hope. They mention that negotiations have opened pathways for humanitarian aid, and they are doing what they can in their public health role to contribute. The article includes images of medical supplies waiting at the border in Egypt and humanitarian aid provided by the UN in Dubai.

title: Morning Trade Note (10/12/23)
summary: The article discusses a compelling investment opportunity that the author wants to share with their subscribers. They believe that the stock has the potential for a 60-80% upside based on its current price. The author encourages readers to dive into the details and hopes they are reading the article with a warm cup of coffee.

title: Resonance Consultancy Reveals the 2024 Best Cities
summary: Resonance, a leading advisor in tourism, real estate, and economic development, has released its ninth annual World's Best Cities rankings. The rankings analyze key statistics, user-generated reviews, social media, and online activity to determine the relative quality, reputation, and competitive identity of urban centers. The rankings aim to identify the top 100 places to live, visit, and invest in. The overall Best Cities rankings are determined by analyzing each city's performance across 24 metrics, which are grouped into Livability, Lovability, and Prosperity. The top 10 best cities for 2024, according to the rankings, are London, Paris, New York, Tokyo, Singapore, Dubai, San Francisco, Barcelona, Amsterdam, and Seoul. These cities are seen as leading the planet in post-pandemic economic recovery and a resilient future. The rankings provide valuable insights for individuals and businesses looking to make informed decisions about where to live, visit, or invest. The full report and city profiles can be accessed on the WorldsBestCities.com website.

title: Goodbye Twitter, Hello Notes
summary: The author, an early adopter of Twitter, created an account in 2008 but deleted it less than a year later. In 2010, they created a new account due to fear of missing out (FOMO). Now, after 13 years and 20K followers, the author is leaving Twitter. The reasons for leaving are not important, but it is not because of their followers or trolls. The author no longer enjoys using the platform and has changed their Twitter profile, deleted the app, and will no longer check the streams. They have decided to exclusively post on Substack Notes, with some auto-posts on Twitter for their followers who are not on Notes. The author will still be active on The Lund Loop Discord. In conclusion, the author is leaving Twitter and inviting others to join them on Substack Notes.

title: EM Fund Stock Picks & Country Commentaries (October 10, 2023)
summary: In a recent podcast interview, Juan Torres, a fund manager on the Schroder Global Value Team, discussed the opportunities and challenges of value investing in emerging markets. Torres highlighted that many emerging markets resemble the American markets in the 1930s, with inefficiencies and uncertainty, making them a fertile ground for value investing. He emphasized the importance of reducing Type 1 errors to improve investment performance and discussed the unique political risks of investing in China. Torres also touched on the underperformance of value investing and emerging markets in the past decade and the challenge of valuing companies with exponential growth potential. He advised investors to stay on the right side of information asymmetries and protect their portfolios from existential risks. Torres emphasized that not all emerging markets are created equal and discussed the importance of screening for stocks in these markets. He also highlighted the need for emerging market investors to have English accounts and to be comfortable with International Financial Reporting Standards. Overall, Torres provided valuable insights and advice for investors looking to navigate the complexities of value investing in emerging markets.

The article includes a look at key Colombian economic data and provides information on some individual Colombian stocks that investors may consider.
