title: Atrocities in Israel
summary: The author shares his thoughts on the recent events in Israel, expressing his pain and concern for the safety of his loved ones. He criticizes the barbaric behavior of some individuals and predicts a shift in Western media's support for Israel once images of dead Palestinians start circulating. The author quotes Golda Meir's statement about peace and forgiveness and reflects on the complex emotions and anger he has experienced. He decides to reduce his consumption of social media and encourages his children to do the same to protect their mental well-being. He also channels his energy into helping the victims of the conflict by asking his Twitter followers to suggest reputable charities in Israel. The author and his family make donations to these charities and offer a signed copy of his book as a thank-you to those who donate $100 or more. The article concludes by mentioning the author's upcoming seasonal letter to his clients, which will discuss various topics related to the economy and investing.

title: My Thoughts on the Economy
summary: The author discusses their thoughts on the economy in a listicle-style format. They highlight the impact of government spending and deficits, the potential consequences of rising interest rates, the importance of the housing sector, the challenges faced by the office real estate market, and the risks associated with higher unemployment. The author emphasizes their conservative investment strategy, focusing on noncyclical businesses, maintaining a margin of safety, and being patient for opportunities. They also stress the importance of understanding the companies in one's portfolio and not being afraid to hold cash when necessary. The author concludes by sharing a personal anecdote about Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 3 and provides a link to listen to the symphony.

title: Unions: From Stimulant for the Economy to Cancer
summary: The article discusses the role of unions in the US and argues that while they have historically played an important role in improving working conditions and protecting workers' rights, they have now become a hindrance to industries and the economy as a whole. The author argues that unions have evolved into a cancer that is slowly killing the industries they are trying to save. The article highlights the negative impact of unions on industries such as ports and automakers, where union demands for higher wages and benefits, as well as restrictions on automation, have made these industries less competitive and less efficient. The author also criticizes the difficulty of firing union members and the toxic workplace culture that unions can create. The article concludes by advocating for a more free-market approach to labor relations, where companies can compete for talent and workers have the freedom to choose their employers.

title: 3 things I've learned after foolishly deciding to start a therapy fund a year ago
summary: The New Fatherhood, a newsletter and community for dads, has launched a therapy fund to help fathers struggling with mental health issues. The fund aims to provide financial aid to dads who need therapy but may not be able to afford it. The initiative was inspired by the founder's own experience with mental health after becoming a father. The fund operates by taking a portion of the newsletter's proceeds and directly giving it to dads in need. However, the process has faced challenges, including difficulties in raising awareness and reaching out to dads who require support. Additionally, the complexity of the US medical system has posed obstacles in finding therapists who can work with US-based clients. Despite these challenges, the therapy fund has already raised a significant amount of money and has helped more dads this year compared to the previous year. The New Fatherhood encourages readers to contribute to the fund by becoming paid subscribers, with their subscription fees going towards helping dads in need.

title: The Empire Strikes Brick
summary: The author discusses how he used a bribe reward chart to encourage his son to sleep through the night, promising a new game for the Nintendo Switch as a reward. He bought the Lego Star Wars game and placed it on the shelf, promising to unwrap it once his son accumulated enough stickers on the chart. The author describes the joy of playing the game with his son, highlighting the drop-in/drop-out co-op system that allows them to play together. He also mentions how the game has sparked his son's interest in Star Wars and led to a renewed obsession with the franchise. The author reflects on the value of spending time playing video games with his son and the importance of being open-minded to the opportunities that modern media presents. He hopes that the memories they create while playing the game will be cherished by his son in the future.

title: Real estate conundrum, Retail sales still well below trend & Don't lose your makers (skilled producers)
summary: Real estate is a popular outlet for savings, but there is skepticism about whether the stock market can replace it due to its complexity and unfamiliarity. However, there is a need to find an alternative to real estate, as it accounts for a significant portion of annual economic activity. Constraints such as affordability and leverage prevent real estate from becoming too hot, as it could lead to a major economic and social crisis. In China, the real estate market has become the center of the economy, with local governments benefiting from land sales and families investing in apartments. However, the reliance on real estate has led to a conundrum, as stopping the process of rising prices would cause tremendous pain throughout the economy. The resolution of this issue is expected to be time-consuming and uncertain. Distressed-debt investors who bought bonds from Evergrande, a Chinese real estate company, are realizing that the restructuring process will be overseen by the government and depend on its future plans for the firm.

title: Issue #120 - What Did We Really Learn from China's October Golden Week Holiday?
summary: China's October Golden Week, a major holiday period, saw impressive travel statistics, including 826 million domestic trips and 14.22 million air passengers. However, the travel economy is still recovering, and the future of China's outbound travel remains uncertain. Chinese brands have excelled at marketing to Chinese consumers, operating at a speed that is hard to match. Chinese social media plays a significant role in driving the quest for new travel experiences, with user-generated content trusted more than brand-created content. China's high-speed rail network has become pivotal in trip planning and destination marketing, attracting younger travelers and offering appealing onboard services. China also has a unique take on over-tourism, with some destinations becoming overrun during Golden Week. South East Asian destinations, which heavily rely on Chinese tourists, have had to manage their expectations due to decreased international air capacity and gradual demand. It is important for destinations and travel suppliers to avoid over-emphasizing the three Golden Weeks and instead focus on year-round opportunities.

title: Road Trip: Southern California
summary: The author of the Gregor Letter is taking a break to visit colleges in Los Angeles and San Diego with their high school senior. They will be touring various engineering schools and also attending a football game. The author mentions that Metro has received funding for the LA River Path Project. The letter will return on October 30th.

title: Idea Brunch with Sean Westropp of Deep Sail Capital
summary: Sean Westropp, the chief investment officer of Deep Sail Capital, a long/short equity fund, discusses his investment strategy and approach to managing the fund's short book. Deep Sail focuses on microcaps, special situations, and quality growth on the long side, and potential frauds, pump and dumps, and fads on the short side. Westropp explains that the "right ponds" for the fund are industries with high returns on capital invested, stable growth trajectories, high barriers to entry, and little commodity exposure. He also outlines the four pillars of an exceptional investment that the fund uses to evaluate potential investments. In terms of managing the short book, Westropp emphasizes the importance of valuation and sets criteria for short positions, such as avoiding companies with a short-borrow rate above 30%. He also highlights IPO hangovers, industry bubbles, pump and dumps, and growth deceleration as areas to look for short opportunities. Westropp concludes by discussing how Deep Sail Capital finds off-the-beaten-path ideas through a mix of screeners, investor networks, Twitter, and thematic-driven ideas. He shares three contrarian ideas on his radar, including Inmode, an Israel-based medical device company.

title: Berentzen Group
summary: German liquor and soft drinks producer Berentzen Group is undervalued on various financial metrics. The company has a long history, starting in 1758, and has gone through various changes and acquisitions over the years. The majority of its revenue comes from the spirits segment, with traditional German drinks like Berentzen and Pushkin Vodka being the main brands. The spirits segment has solid pricing power and good returns on capital. The non-alcoholic segment represents a smaller portion of revenue, with the Mio Mio brand being the growth driver. Mio Mio is a mate soft drink that is growing rapidly. The company has reduced its low-margin contract bottling business and is focusing on its owned brands and private labels. Berentzen also has a segment for fresh fruit machines, which has been stable but not impressive in terms of growth. The company also has other smaller segments, such as a museum experience and sales to the tourism industry in Turkey. Overall, Berentzen Group's strategy, management, market position, valuation, and capital allocation are factors to consider when evaluating the company.

title: Saving some brief updates (premium)
summary: Spirit Airlines and JetBlue Airways are currently involved in a trial. The author provides three updates on the trial. The first update is about a podcast that discusses the trial. The second update is about a motion filed by Spirit Airlines to dismiss the case. The third update is about a ruling by the judge that allows the case to proceed.

title: Value Punks' Daye Deng talks Warren Buffett's $BRK investment into Japanese Trading Companies (podcast #201)
summary: Daye Deng, Co-Founder and Editor of the Value Punks newsletter, discusses his articles on Japanese Trading Companies and Warren Buffett's investment in Japan. The podcast is sponsored by Stream by AlphaSense. Deng's deep dives explore the reasons behind Buffett's interest in Japan and the potential opportunities in Japanese Trading Companies. The podcast is available on Spotify, iTunes, and YouTube. Deng emphasizes that the podcast and blog do not provide financial advice.

title: Weekend thoughts: investing in inflections and Buffett's airline / railroad investments
summary: The article discusses the concept of "inflection" in investing, where recognizing and capitalizing on industry changes can lead to significant returns. The author provides examples of inflections in the auto industry and the cable industry, highlighting how understanding these changes can lead to profitable investment opportunities. The article also mentions Warren Buffett's successful investments in railroads and airlines, where he recognized industry inflections and made profitable moves. The author concludes by suggesting that there may be an inflection point in antitrust enforcement and merger arbitrage investing. Overall, the article emphasizes the importance of identifying and acting upon inflection points in order to generate alpha in investing.

title: The Antitrust Inflection
summary: The author discusses the investment opportunities in merger arbitrage and antitrust investing, highlighting the recent Microsoft-Activision deal as an example. They argue that there has been a shift in the regulatory environment, with regulators pursuing novel antitrust cases and big companies getting bigger being seen as bad. This has created opportunities for investors to make uncorrelated returns by betting on the outcome of these cases. The author believes that the market has been slow to recognize this change and continues to price these cases as coin flips, presenting ongoing investment opportunities. They mention several potential opportunities, including Seagen, Albertson, iRobot, and Spirit Airlines, and emphasize the need for careful analysis of each individual case and the broader regulatory landscape. The author concludes that the investment opportunity in merger arbitrage and antitrust investing could last for years, but acknowledges the uncertainties and risks involved.

title: Boyar Research's Jonathan Boyar on how $MODG is growing an entire industry (podcast #202)
summary: Jonathan Boyar, President of Boyar Research, returns to the podcast to discuss his thesis on Topgolf Callaway Brands (NASDAQ: MODG) and how it is growing an entire industry. Boyar explains that Topgolf is not just a golf entertainment company, but a technology-driven platform that is revolutionizing the way people engage with the sport. He highlights the company's unique business model, which combines the elements of a driving range, a sports bar, and a social gathering place. Boyar believes that Topgolf has the potential to disrupt the traditional golf industry and attract a new generation of players. He also discusses the recent merger between Topgolf and Callaway, stating that it will further enhance the company's growth prospects. Boyar concludes by emphasizing the long-term investment opportunity that Topgolf presents, as it continues to expand its footprint and innovate in the golf industry.

title: Saga Furs: A net-net and soon monopolistic Business
summary: Saga Furs, an auction house that sells furs, offers an opportunity to buy a business at a low valuation with a clear catalyst for growth. The largest competitor, Kopenhagen Fur, is set to liquidate in 2025, potentially allowing Saga Furs to gain market share. Saga Furs generates revenue through commissions charged to farmers and buyers at their auctions, as well as interest income from delayed payments. The company has historically struggled with negative earnings due to low fur prices and fixed costs, but higher sales could unlock operating leverage. The correlation between fur prices and Saga Furs' profit suggests that prices may rise in 2024. The author predicts that Saga Furs could take a significant portion of Kopenhagen Fur's market share and potentially achieve a monopolistic position. The company's clean balance sheet, with ample cash and little debt, and its asset-light business model further support its investment potential. While future earnings and price targets are uncertain, the author believes that buying Saga Furs at a low valuation presents a low-risk opportunity for potential profit.

title: Cracking Coconuts
summary: Vita Coco, a leading coconut water brand, has released its 2022 shareholder letter, emphasizing the need for beverages to offer more than just refreshment. The company's founders, Michael Kirban and Ira Liran, recognized the untapped potential of the coconut water market in the US in 2003 and established a strong supply chain by partnering with coconut product manufacturers in various countries. Despite facing competition from industry giants like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo, Vita Coco has emerged as the category leader in the US, with approximately 50% market share. The company has also expanded its focus to serve private label demand, particularly from Costco, which accounts for about 30% of its sales. However, Vita Coco recently announced the transition of its supply relationship with its largest private label customer, which is believed to be Costco. This development raises concerns about the long-term differentiation of Vita Coco's brand from private label offerings. The financial implications of this transition have not been quantified, but it is estimated to be around $50 million per year. Despite this setback, Vita Coco remains a dominant player in the coconut water market, which has grown to nearly $700 million in annual retail sales in the US.

title: "It's About Returns, Not Growth"
summary: Ally Financial, a banking company, is facing challenges in the form of credit losses and net interest margin (NIM) pressures. The CEO, Jeff Brown, has announced his resignation, adding to the concerns about the company's performance. Despite these difficulties, Ally's deposit gathering franchise remains strong, with retail deposits crossing $140 billion in Q3 FY23. The company has added over 300,000 net new retail deposit customers this year. However, the interest rate environment has led to increased deposit costs, putting pressure on NIM. In Q3 FY23, deposit costs were around 4.0%, up 250 basis points from the previous year. The NIM contracted by over 50 basis points YoY, impacting short-term earnings. Ally's credit performance has also been affected, with retail auto net charge-offs increasing to 1.85% in Q3. Despite these challenges, management expects NIM to stabilize and gradually expand in the future.

title: Round up, wind up
summary: The article consists of excerpts from various blog posts written by the author. The topics covered include fascism, the influence of the plutocracy, virtual reality, the cost of future well-being, the greediness of the United States, the nature of fascism and its leaders, the commodification of healthcare, the need for political change, different kinds of representation, the problems with a two-party system, Taiwan's status, systemic injustice, AI alignment, the state as a coordination mechanism, and the relationship between the state and the market. The author explores these topics and offers their insights and perspectives on each issue.

title: "The Next Energy Domino: Natural Gas"
summary: The article provides an update on the oil and natural gas market. WTI oil has reached the expected base case of $92.10 but is currently experiencing a pullback. Brent oil has broken the downtrend channel and reached a significant resistance level. The outlook for crude oil is consolidation before moving higher. A study by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis found that a 10% increase in natural gas prices can lead to a 0.2% increase in the Consumer Price Index (CPI). The article also provides outlooks for natural gas and WTI oil. Natural gas shows signs of a potential rally in the near term, while WTI oil is likely to consolidate and retreat from current levels. The article concludes that the outlook for oil and gas is bullish in the short term, but there are factors that could keep prices rangebound. Natural gas is becoming more attractive, and there is potential for upside in the coming months.

title: Gold & Silver Breaking Support
summary: Gold and silver prices are at risk of significant declines as real yields break out to new highs. The recent strength in gold was due to US regional bank failures and speculation of a higher China premium to global prices. However, even a partial catch-up with real yields could lead to a decline in precious metals. Silver, in particular, is at risk of a sharp decline as it no longer has a high correlation to gold and has industrial uses. The article suggests that if the gold triangle pattern break is verified, there could be meaningful declines in precious metals. The base case price target for gold is $1,700. For silver, if the bear flag thesis is correct, prices should break below $22.15 and gain momentum, with a price target of $15.25. The article also mentions that gold volatility has recently moved sharply and may need a pause before heading higher. Overall, the divergence between gold and real yields suggests that gold may need to catch up in the future.

title: Post-Policy Response of UK And US Bond Market
summary: The Bank of England and the Federal Reserve Board have kept their interest rates unchanged, but the reactions in the bond market have been different. The UK Gilt yield curve has bull steepened, while the US yield curve has bear steepened. The British pound has weakened against the Euro and US Dollar, indicating that market participants are unwinding their positions in rates and currencies. Short positions against Gilts were likely curve trades against European bonds. The market suggests a sharp UK slowdown in the short term as the likely outcome. The US Friday reversal may well create a softening in yield in the short term, but it is likely a pause for yet higher yields. Two out of three key US equity indices confirm an H&S pattern. The Russell 2000 and S&P 500 have broken their H&S patterns, while the Nasdaq 100 is at crucial support. The UK Gilt yields are close to breaking down, especially in the curve's 2- and 5-year parts. The oversold momentum indicators are the only things going for the British Pound (GBP), which is insufficient to call for a sustainable bounce. The sharp move in yields last week should be seen in a near one-year consolidation pattern in 10- and 30-year yields. A bond bid due to an equity selloff is unlikely if the decline is measured and not unruly. A 35-year bond bull market unwinds will never be sideways, nor will it end when most think it has fallen too far and cannot fall much further.

title: Doom, Gloom and no Boom
summary: The Moneyweek Conference 2023 in London featured presentations from Ruffer and GMO that highlighted concerning trends. Alex Chartres of Ruffer discussed the end of a golden age and the emergence of a new world order and cold war. He also raised concerns about China's deflationary pressures, particularly in the property market, which could have serious implications for the economy. Other issues discussed included the impact of climate change, declining fertility rates, the return of the big state, and financial repression. Chartres concluded that the biggest risk for investors is inflation and financial repression, and recommended being more active, owning real assets, and being anti-fragile to preserve wealth. Ruffer also shared a list of "lobster pot" stocks that are easy to get into but hard to get out of, with China being a major factor in many of them.

title: Western leftists have lost the plot
summary: The article discusses the support for the Palestinian cause by the Democratic Socialists of America (DSA) and other leftists in the wake of the Israel-Hamas war. The author highlights the disturbing behavior and rhetoric displayed by some leftists, including celebrating the targeting of civilians and making anti-Semitic remarks. The article also points out the lack of moral consistency among these leftists, as they support Hamas' actions but refuse to support Ukraine's defense against Russian occupation. The author suggests that the Western leftist movement has fallen to a deep sickness and that their support for the Palestinian cause is driven by opposition to the West rather than genuine concern for human rights. The article concludes by stating that this episode will likely damage the leftist movement's reputation among progressive Americans.

title: A Nobel for the story of women in the workforce
summary: Claudia Goldin has been awarded the 2023 Nobel Prize in Economics for her work on women's labor market outcomes. Goldin is recognized as one of the pioneers of the "credibility revolution" in empirical economics, which focuses on using natural experiments to test hypotheses. Her research has shown the impact of technological innovations, such as the birth control pill, on women's careers and marriage decisions. Goldin's methodology is broad and eclectic, incorporating theories, cultural norms, politics, and economic history. She has created new data sets and uncovered trends in women's employment, highlighting the complex factors that influence women's economic situation. While progress has been made in reducing gender inequalities, Goldin's research also shows that women still face a tradeoff between child-rearing and careers. She suggests that remote work could be a solution to advancing gender equality by providing more flexibility in the workplace. Goldin's work demonstrates the power of understanding social problems at their functional level and using knowledge to reshape the world.

title: At least five interesting things for the end of your week (#16)
summary: In this article, the author discusses various topics, including podcasts, Michael Lewis's defense of Sam Bankman-Fried, national security threats, America's lack of building, and the impact of shoplifting on Target stores. The author highlights a podcast episode on the Israel-Gaza war and an interview on national security threats. They also question Michael Lewis's defense of Sam Bankman-Fried, suspecting that there is solid evidence of deliberate malfeasance. The author emphasizes the importance of allies in winning wars and suggests that the US needs to get the rest of the world on its side in dealing with Russia and China. They criticize America's lack of building and the challenges posed by NEPA, a law that allows people to sue projects for cumbersome paperwork. The author also examines the impact of shoplifting on Target stores and the reliability of data on shoplifting incidents. Finally, they discuss the evidence that building market-rate housing lowers rents.

title: We're not ready for the Big One
summary: The article discusses the increasing likelihood of a war between the US and China over Taiwan. The author argues that the world is slipping into a more warlike state due to the waning of American deterrence and the rise of the "New Axis" (Russia-Iran-China axis) against the US and its allies. The author points out that China has been preparing for war, with constant military exercises around Taiwan and state media airing programs about an attack on Taiwan. The author warns that most Americans are not mentally prepared for a US-China war and urges for preparation and anticipation. The article concludes by addressing skepticism about the possibility of a war over Taiwan and emphasizes that if China attacks Taiwan, it will likely attack US bases first.

title: At least five interesting things for the middle of your week (#17)
summary: The article discusses various topics, including the importance of taking care of rabbits, the resurgence of techno-optimism, the strong performance of the U.S. economy, China's ongoing real estate woes, the economic inefficiency of slavery, and the negative impact of social media platforms. The author highlights the need to pay attention to the well-being of rabbits and shares a rescue organization's request for help. They also discuss the techno-optimism expressed by Marc Andreessen, who believes that technology can bring abundance and improve human lives. The article further explores the positive economic growth in the U.S. post-pandemic, contrasting it with China's struggling real estate sector. It also challenges the notion that slavery was economically beneficial, presenting evidence that it was inefficient and harmful to the economy. Lastly, the article discusses the divisive nature of social media platforms and their role in amplifying extremist discourse. The author emphasizes the need for society to adapt to these technologies and find ways to resist their negative effects.

title: Economic possibilities for Gaza
summary: The article discusses the ongoing conflict in Gaza and the need to focus on the long-term economic development of the region. It highlights the lack of support and attention given to the people of Gaza by various parties involved, including Hamas, Israel, Egypt, and other Arab countries. The author argues that economic development can provide a purpose other than violence and can help in making decisions about leadership. The article suggests that Gaza has the potential to become an economically flourishing place, citing examples of other countries that have recovered from war and repressive governments. The author presents a vision for the economic future of Gaza, including raising per capita GDP to $10,000 and targeting specific industries for growth. The article acknowledges that achieving this vision would require national self-determination, an end to external conflicts, and long-term political stability. The author concludes by emphasizing the importance of having a picture in mind of the potential benefits of economic development for Gaza.

title: Thoughts on techno-optimism
summary: Techno-optimism can be divided into two categories: positive and normative. Positive techno-optimism believes that there is still a lot of untapped technological potential to be discovered, while normative techno-optimism believes that new technology will make the world a better place. Techno-optimism can also be active or passive, with active optimism believing that technology will progress and improve human life only if the appropriate actions are taken. The author subscribes to both positive and normative techno-optimism but leans more towards active optimism. They believe that technology expands society's collective set of choices and that humans should be given as much choice as possible. However, they acknowledge that society's choices may not always align with individual choices and that technology can be used for both good and evil. The author also argues that sustaining technological progress requires a whole-of-society approach and the collaboration of various institutions. They emphasize the importance of society using technology responsibly and for the greater good. Finally, the author believes that sustainability is not an enemy of techno-optimism but rather a core part of it, as innovation is necessary to sustain technological society into the future.

title: Monetary Policy in a Surplus Economy
summary: The article discusses the concept of supply and demand constraints in the economy, drawing on the work of economist János Kornai. It explains how state ownership of property in planned economies leads to resource-constrained shortages, while private ownership in market economies leads to demand-constrained surpluses. The article then discusses the recent reemergence of acute shortages in the global economy, caused by overwhelming demand and supply-side constraints. It highlights the role of monetary policy in addressing these shortages and the need for a balance between tightening policy to harden firms' budget constraints and hoping for supply-side capacity to return. The article also discusses the easing of supply constraints in various sectors, such as advanced manufacturing, energy, and food production, leading to increased output and stabilization of prices. It emphasizes that the stabilization in prices has primarily come from improvements in supply rather than contractions in demand. The article concludes by noting the importance of hardening global budget constraints to end the shortage economy and the need for central banks to prevent runaway price increases.

title: ESG Bites - Week of 10/13/23
summary: The article discusses the genetic variation and malleability of dogs, highlighting the wide range of physical and temperamental characteristics seen among domesticated dogs. The author explains that dogs have a high incidence of variant single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in their DNA, which are single nucleotide differences between a dog's two matching chromosomes. The article also mentions the existence of unique canine-specific short interspersed elements (SINEs) in dog DNA, which can turn gene functions off and on or amplify/dampen gene expression. The author reflects on their recently passed dog, Fiona, and the special bond between humans and dogs. The article concludes by discussing the Department of Justice's lawsuit against eBay for enabling the sale of "rolling coal" devices, which pump more diesel into a vehicle's engine to emit sooty black clouds of exhaust. The lawsuit claims that eBay enabled the sale of over 343,000 of these devices, which could result in fines under the Clean Air Act.

title: Speedwell Weekly Recap
summary: The article discusses various topics covered in recent episodes of The Synopsis podcast, including an analysis of Copart's business model and the Consumer's Hierarchy of Preferences framework. It also mentions Speedwell Research's report on Etsy, highlighting the company's growth and challenges in increasing buyer frequency. The article provides links to the podcast episodes and podcast transcripts, as well as other interesting links and updates on companies like Casey's General Store and Yahoo!.

title: Quick Value #189 - 10.16.23 ($HRBR)
summary: The article discusses a regional airline that is currently trading below its book value and has a significant amount of cash and investments. The author mentions that there are several alternative scenarios that have not been explored. title: The Russia Sanctions Need a Reset
summary: The global alliance of democracies has been supporting Ukraine in its war against Russia by providing financial assistance and military hardware. However, despite export controls and financial sanctions, Russia has been able to import what it needs for its military from the same countries that are supporting Ukraine. Russia's imports of manufactured goods have rebounded and remained steady, with exports from the EU and other democracies being routed through third countries. The Russian government initially restricted the data it published on imports, but has now resumed publishing monthly data. This is a serious problem as many exports going to Russia are coming from the allied democracies, including sophisticated machine tools necessary for military equipment. Extreme sanctions on Russian oil and gas exports have also proven ineffective, as the Russian government does not pay for anything using oil and gas, but rather relies on the ability to tap into the resources of productive societies through imports. Limiting the revenues from oil and gas exports is not enough to defend Ukraine as long as manufacturers continue to supply the Russian military industry with necessary equipment and components.

title: Tracking Russia's Financial Outflows, Again
summary: Russia's current account surplus has increased significantly since the invasion of Ukraine, as import spending decreased more than export revenues. In the first half of 2022, Russian residents earned $74 billion more than they spent each quarter on average. However, recent data suggests that the surplus has shrunk to an average of $14 billion per quarter in 2023. Despite the decrease in the surplus, there is still a discrepancy between Russian and non-Russian data, making it difficult to interpret the situation accurately. Capital flight is believed to be the main reason for the financial outflows from Russia since the start of the war.

title: New Episode of UN/BALANCED!
summary: China's increasing surplus in motor vehicle exports is explored in this episode of UN/BALANCED. The implications of this surge and its potential impact on European rebalancing are discussed. The episode also delves into a debate about the effectiveness of tariffs. Paid subscribers to The Overshoot are eligible for a discount to UN/BALANCED.

title: Super-Spiked Videopods (EP31): Geopolitics and Transition Turmoil
summary: The article discusses the long-term implications of geopolitical turmoil on the energy sector, particularly in light of recent events such as the terrorist attack in Israel and stock market turmoil among energy transition companies. The article highlights the massive unmet energy needs of the global population and the potential for growth in both new technologies and traditional energy sources. However, there is a lack of calls for oil and gas companies to increase capital expenditure, and the decline in New Energies equities suggests slower growth in that sector. The article also mentions rising tensions in the Middle East and the ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine, which could impact OPEC spare capacity and energy commodity prices. The traditional energy sector is seen as under-appreciated, and there may be value in some New Energies equities in the future. Overall, the article emphasizes the need to consider both geopolitical risks and the energy transition when analyzing the energy sector.

title: Investing Lessons From The Walgreens Stock Collapse
summary: The article introduces a new series called Fundamentals, which will focus on business case studies and investing topics from an educational perspective. The series aims to provide readers with valuable insights and knowledge. The author invites feedback and encourages readers to share their thoughts on the new series.

summary: Investment newsletter Deep Dive provides an update on the performance of its stock recommendations. The newsletter has covered 240 stocks and made 74 directional picks since its launch in March 2022. The average return of +6.6% is in line with the S&P 500, with most of the gains coming from short positions. The newsletter plans to compare its performance to the Russell 2000 in the future. The article highlights two stocks that still look attractive: Nathan's Famous, which has returned 51% since being recommended, and Coherent, which recently made a $1 billion deal to strengthen its position in growth markets. The article also mentions that Clearfield has been a disappointment but may be intriguing at its current lows. The newsletter takes pride in its performance but acknowledges the need for improvement. It plans to take a closer look at past recommendations and continues to work towards better performance.

title: Topgolf's Path To 150% Gains
summary: Shares in a popular consumer leisure company have experienced a significant decline, with short sellers continuing to put pressure on the stock. The company is facing challenges such as slowing venue sales and a high level of debt. However, the business is performing better than what critics suggest, leading to the possibility of it being a value trap. Despite the risks involved, there is potential for substantial gains, making it a worthwhile investment opportunity.

title: The Problem With P/E Multiples (And What To Do About It)
summary: SentinelOne, a cybersecurity stock, has the highest forward price-to-earnings (P/E) multiple in the market, trading at over 5,000 times its earnings for the following fiscal year. However, this high multiple is due to the company's low estimated earnings, not its valuation. The P/E multiple is a useful piece of information when combined with a sense of the trajectory of earnings, but it has limitations. It does not determine whether a stock is attractive on its own. Factors such as the growth potential of the business and external influences need to be considered. The P/E multiple is a rule of thumb and should be used as a marker of expectations rather than valuation. It provides a starting point for research, but it's up to the individual investor to determine if the market's expectations are accurate. Low P/E stocks have historically underperformed high P/E stocks, but there is no one right answer in any environment. Investors should conduct their own research and make decisions based on their analysis.

title: Research Notes: Ozempic Rattles The Market
summary: The market value of GLP-1 weight loss drugs, such as Ozempic and Wegovy, has surged in recent months, with Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly experiencing significant gains in market cap. The impact of these drugs extends beyond the pharmaceutical industry, affecting equity valuations and cash flows. The drugs' potential to create significant weight loss has led to a sell-off in food and beverage manufacturers, as well as alcohol purveyors. Investors are also considering the second- and third-order effects of these drugs, such as the potential increase in retail sales as patients on Ozempic require new wardrobes. The drugs' impact on consumer behavior and the market is significant, particularly considering the importance of "super consumers" who drive a large portion of sales for certain industries. However, there are concerns about the long-term effectiveness of GLP-1 drugs and potential side effects. Despite this, there is optimism that GLP-1s could have a transformative effect on society, similar to the birth control pill.

title: 🎙️ | Timen Swijtink, Lacàph and Building a Coffee Brand in Vietnam
summary: Timen Swijtink, founder of Vietnamese coffee brand Lacàph, discusses the importance of storytelling in building a brand and adding value to a product. He emphasizes the need to create a context for consumers and tell the story behind the product, as it adds value and attracts customers who care about where their products come from. Swijtink also shares insights on how to find a way into supermarket shelves, highlighting the importance of building relationships and not being shy about putting oneself out there. He advises entrepreneurs to be prepared for rejection and constructive feedback, and to figure out how to get the attention of potential buyers. Swijtink also discusses the coffee culture in Vietnam, the difference between Robusta and Arabica beans, and Lacàph's relationship with coffee farmers. He concludes by recommending the book "Power" by Professor Pfeffer, which explores the concept of power and how to manage it effectively.

title: Open Letter to the Yang Di-Petuan Agong regarding the International Health Regulations
summary: A coalition of NGOs, health practitioners, and lawyers in Malaysia has issued a warning notice to the government regarding the objection period for the World Health Organization (WHO) Convention Agreement (WHO CA+) and International Health Amendments Regulations 2005 (IHR2005). They argue that these amendments threaten the safety and national sovereignty of Malaysia. The coalition claims that if the government fails to object before December 1, 2023, it would violate the national constitution and the basic rights of the people. They also highlight that the amendments could potentially take away the power of the Yang di-Pertuan Agong (the King) in declaring emergencies, which is a criminal offense under the Penal Code. The coalition points out that other countries, such as Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom, have already gathered signatures and made statements objecting to the WHO CA+ and IHR2005 amendments. They urge Malaysia to take similar action to protect its sovereignty.

title: Growing Groundswell to Pardon Malaysia’s Najib
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, who is currently serving a 12-year sentence for corruption related to the 1MDB scandal, is facing an intense campaign for his release. Supporters of the 70-year-old economist have organized a "National Townhall for Justice Roadshow" to advocate for a royal pardon. However, it is unlikely that Najib can be pardoned unless his other court cases are dismissed. Despite being in jail, Najib remains a powerful political figure and is believed to control a significant amount of political funds. Many fear that without him, Malaysia could fall into the hands of Islamist fundamentalists. However, it is important to remember Najib's involvement in corruption and other crimes. Police found a massive amount of stolen wealth, including jewelry, handbags, and cash, at his residence. He is also accused of ordering the murder of a former lover who knew too much about the 1MDB scandal. If Najib is pardoned, he could potentially regain power and continue his corrupt practices.

title: Something on Hamas from OSTB
summary: The article discusses the recent conflict between Hamas and Israel, highlighting the lack of voice and representation for the people of Gaza. It points out that there have been no free elections in Gaza for the past 17 years, and the leaders of Hamas, like Ismail Haniyeh, do not live in Gaza and do not have the mandate of the people. The author questions who made the decision for Hamas to go to war and suggests that they may have received instructions from the Muslim Brotherhood in Qatar or Iran. The article argues that Hamas has no chance of victory against Israel, as Israel has a much larger military and controls essential resources like water, food, and electricity in Gaza. The author speculates that Hamas may have started the war to gain financial support and remind the world of its existence. The article concludes by suggesting that the conflict in the Middle East will continue for decades due to the competing interests of Iran, Saudi Arabia, and other Arab states, and criticizes the region's leaders as being "insane."

title: Hezbollah is already in the United States
summary: Hezbollah, a terrorist organization with a strong presence in Latin America, has a longstanding relationship with the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps and is involved in criminal activities such as money laundering and human smuggling. They have a particularly robust relationship with the Communist regime in Venezuela, where they work together to build transnational organized crime networks. Hezbollah operatives are provided with state-sponsored cover identities and access to Venezuela's airline and banking systems, allowing them to move freely in the Western Hemisphere. The influx of Venezuelans crossing the US southern border provides an opportunity for Hezbollah operatives to infiltrate the country. Hezbollah is known for its long-term planning and stockpiling of explosives, as well as cultivating contacts for firearms. They have also created target packages on potential targets in cities like New York, Chicago, and Washington, D.C. Despite the focus on the Middle East, it is important to recognize that Hezbollah is already present in the United States and poses a significant threat.

title: The Day Of Rage – Bringing The War Home
summary: The article discusses how Hamas has infiltrated left-wing activist groups in the United States, and raises concerns about the extent to which the Australian left may also be compromised. The Students for Justice in Palestine (SJP) is highlighted as a group at the heart of the growing "protest" movement, which has been linked to terror groups such as Hamas, Hezbollah, and the Marxist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP). The SJP is also connected to the American Muslims for Palestine (AMP), an organization whose leaders include former Islamic terrorists. The article argues that these radical leftist groups, including SJP, are not simply protesting but explicitly calling for violence and destruction in solidarity with Hamas. Law enforcement agencies across the US have gone on alert in response to the rising threat level, with enhanced security measures and increased patrols of Jewish houses of worship, Jewish-owned businesses, and Israeli diplomatic buildings. The article concludes by suggesting that the nation has lost its way, citing examples such as the US President giving billions to the ayatollahs and the President's special envoy to Iran having his security clearance suspended for giving classified information to Iran.

title: Australia’s rejection of “The Voice” is not a throwback of Indigenous Australians
summary: The article discusses the rejection of 'The Voice', a referendum in Australia that aimed to establish a 24-member advisory board for Indigenous Australians. The referendum was overwhelmingly rejected, with only around 40% voting in favor and at least 5 states not carrying the constitutional amendment. Many Indigenous Australians also voted against 'The Voice' due to concerns about representation and the fear that it would be controlled by self-appointed activists. The article highlights the failure of the 'yes' campaign to address these concerns and the labeling of 'no' voters as racist. It also raises questions about the allocation of funds for Indigenous Australians and the lack of transparency and accountability. The article suggests that the defeat of 'The Voice' referendum may set back the cause of Indigenous Australians and calls for further investigation into corruption and the representation of Indigenous Australians. The article concludes by comparing the referendum to the failed 1999 referendum on Australia becoming a republic and warns of potential consequences for the prime minister.

title: A more of the same budget by the Madani government
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister and Finance Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, delivered the country's largest-ever budget, with RM 393 billion in spending and a budget deficit of RM 86 billion. The government debt is expected to surpass RM 1.5 trillion. The budget papers forecasted growth at 4-5 percent, but there may be a tax collection shortfall if there is an economic slowdown. Little has been done to broaden the tax base, and the focus has been on a 10 percent capital gains tax and a tax on luxury goods. The budget includes spending on SME development, flood mitigation, food security, and welfare, similar to previous governments. Civil servants will receive incentives and increased pension payouts, which make up a significant portion of government expenditure. There is no effort to rein in public sector expenditure, raising concerns about productivity. The budget also includes plans for green initiatives, such as the use of solar panels and electric vehicles, but there are questions about the practicality and the need to import these technologies. The budget has faced criticism for using public funds for infrastructure projects and land purchases by government-linked companies. Overall, the budget has been seen as lacking significant changes in policies.

title: Its now a crime to criticize national leaders?
summary: The Malaysian government has passed an amendment to the Sedition Act, known as the Prevention of Terrorism Act (POTA) 2015. Under this act, individuals who spread defamation against national leaders or alter their image to create hatred on social media platforms can be arrested. The minimum detention period under POTA is 2 years, with a maximum of 20 years. The act cannot be challenged in any court, and the detention center is located on a 1000-acre island in the North of Sabah. It is now an offense to propagate material deemed to be of seditious tendency, and intent is not necessary for sedition. The article questions whether previous governments or prime ministers have enacted similar laws to control social media and whether this aligns with the expectations of a reformist or democratic government.

title: Further use of the Sedition Act for political persecution
summary: Kean Wong, an editor of a book called "Rebirth: Reformasi, Resistance, and Hope in New Malaysia," has been detained by the police in Malaysia for alleged sedition. The book, which contains articles about the 2018 general election, features a reproduction of a painting by Shia Yih Ying on its cover. The police claim that the book insulted the Malaysian Coat of Arms with an improperly modified design. The publisher of the book, Gerakbudaya Sdn. Bhd, had all copies confiscated by the police. Kean Wong's detention raises questions about selective persecution and the government's anti-free speech culture. The investigation into this case has been ongoing for over three years.

title: Government pursues WHO agenda in budget
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, has committed RM 150 million to enhance the Ministry of Health's IT system and pursue the World Health Organization's (WHO) electronic health records (EHR) agenda. The aim is to digitalize health records and make them accessible to authorized users. The Ministry of Health is currently testing a Clinic Management System Subscription (CCMS) and electronic medical records (EMR) in 100 clinics across the country. The long-term goal is to roll out digitalized medical records for every citizen. The WHO sees EHR as a way to provide information and potentially regulate and control travel in the future. The Malaysian government is also supporting the new International Health Regulations (IHR), which would allow the WHO to suspend the Malaysian Constitution in the event of a declared medical emergency.

title: The importance of bloggers to Malaysian politics and society
summary: Bloggers in Malaysia have played a crucial role in exposing political, financial, and social scandals that the mainstream media often ignores or is afraid to cover. They have been the last bastion of investigative journalism in the country. Despite facing scorn and smear campaigns from those they expose, many bloggers continue their work out of love and passion for their country. They have uncovered deficiencies in the royal family, politicians' hypocrisy, and cases of marginalized individuals. They have also exposed corruption, rape, murder, sexual abuse, human trafficking, medical malpractice, and foreign infiltration of the government. However, bloggers face attacks from wealthy corporations who take advantage of weak libel laws. The marginalized in society are often the only ones who support and appreciate the work of bloggers. In a time of media self-censorship, bloggers are essential for shedding light on the realities of Malaysian society.

title: The plight of news portals
summary: Malaysia Now, an online news portal in Malaysia, is facing financial difficulties and can no longer pay its staff. Despite this, the portal has played a significant role in exposing political realities and publishing daring revelations. Over the past three years, Malaysia Now has questioned the actions of politicians, such as the attempt to gift a property worth RM100 million to former prime minister Najib Razak. The portal has also exposed the dealings between Anwar Ibrahim, Ahmad Zahid Hamidi, and Najib in their attempt to topple the government during the Covid-19 pandemic. Malaysia Now has covered stories on marginalized groups, corporate corruption, and statelessness, setting a standard for journalism. The portal has faced harassment and threats from high-ranking officials, but the support from readers has encouraged them to continue reporting, albeit at a reduced capacity. Malaysia Now promises to continue revealing and exposing the truth, even in the face of adversity.

title: Albanese is creating a feudal-strata within the Aboriginal community
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and the 'yes' vote campaign leadership are in denial over the defeat of 'The Voice' referendum, where 61 percent of Australians rejected the proposition. Albanese appeared to blame 'white people' for the defeat and is determined to find a new way to respond to the Uluru Statement, despite the referendum result. Calls for a royal commission into child sexual abuse in Aboriginal communities were rejected by both Labor and the Greens. The refusal to investigate alleged corruption within the 'Aboriginal industry' and child sexual abuse effectively protects a group of elites and marginalizes rural Aboriginals. The government's actions cast doubts over its sincerity and willingness to listen to Aboriginal voices. The article argues that 'The Voice' was never about the welfare of Indigenous Australians but about empowering an activist elite class. Any future proposals from these groups should be treated with skepticism.

title: Brutal eviction of Kampong Sungai Baru residents
summary: The eviction of residents in Kampong Sungai Baru, Malaysia has been postponed until October 31. The private developer, Ritzy Gloss Sdn Bhd, is purchasing the residents' properties for a lower price than market value, with no incentive to negotiate a better deal. Some families are refusing to leave and are prepared to go to prison. The residents are disappointed with Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, who obtained a reprieve but has not intervened further. The evictions are not for public facilities but for the benefit of the developer, with government assistance. The residents, mostly pensioners, were squatters on the land for generations and were provided with the right to residence in the 1970s. The evictions are seen as corporate gangsterism and an example of the elite taking advantage of the powerless residents. The situation highlights the perceived mistreatment of Malays as second-class citizens in their own country.

title: Will PAS joining the ‘unity government’ be the final solution for political stability?
summary: There is speculation about the possibility of PAS joining a 'unity government' in Malaysia, which would include various ethnic and ideological interests. While this idea could be beneficial in terms of creating a broad coalition, it was previously rejected by Muhyiddin Yassin and Abdul Hadi Awang. If PAS were to join, the 'unity government' would have a super-majority in parliament. However, the substance of the government would not change significantly, as key policies would remain the same. The main issue in Malaysian politics is not ideological differences, but rather clashes between personalities. The constant changes in leadership have led to political instability. The 'unity government' could provide stability and clarity for Malaysians, but it needs PAS more than PAS needs it. PAS believes it can form a strong and stable government on its own after the next general election. The 'unity government' must now strategize to maintain power in the upcoming election.

title: 453: Anthropic, Microsoft Athena AI Chip, Nvidia Strikes Back, Antitrust Catch-22, China vs Wind Power, Nobel Immigrants, EV, and JS Bach
summary: China is working to make the rest of the world dependent on it for solar, wind, and lithium supply chains, which could pose a problem if access to Chinese suppliers is cut off. Western wind power companies like Siemens Gamesa are being forced to pull back and outsource production to lower-cost suppliers, many of which are in China. This could lead to a loss of control over crucial infrastructure if Chinese suppliers become inaccessible. The rest of the world should be wary of becoming dependent on China for these supplies, as it would be difficult and costly to regain manufacturing expertise and capacity if access is lost. In other news, Microsoft is reportedly close to unveiling its Athena AI Accelerator Chip, which it has been developing since 2019. The chip is expected to compete with Nvidia's offerings and could provide benefits for hyperscalers by reducing costs and increasing control over hardware. Nvidia, on the other hand, is attempting to reduce its reliance on hyperscalers by building its own cloud service and leasing data center space. However, regulators' attacks on Big Tech are seen as unsavory, and there is a need for a substantive debate on how to best deal with the power amassed by these companies. Finally, high-skilled immigration is highlighted as a policy lever for innovation, with immigrants representing a significant portion of Nobel Prize winners in the US.

title: 454: Biggest Bond Crash in 150 Years, Microsoft + Activision, ARM, Wikipedia, Jimmy Buffett, Semiconductors, and Tokyo Digital Twin
summary: The article discusses the concept of getting unstuck creatively by trying new paths and experimenting with different ideas. The author shares their experience of using generative AI to create images of lighthouses and how they found inspiration by exploring a new technique. They emphasize the importance of being open to different directions and conducting small experiments to find what works. The article also touches on the phenomenon of perspective shift as one grows older and reflects on the immaturity of past experiences. In addition, the article mentions the current state of the bond market, highlighting that it is experiencing the biggest rout in 150 years. The author explains that the frequency of "once-in-a-century" events may be due to statistical misunderstanding, evolving baselines, increased detection and reporting, and the independence of different domains. They caution against relying on rare events to be rare in one's own life.

title: 455: Rolex Pricing, Jensen & Nvidia, China Chip Ban 1.5, Costco, Google Maps to Optimize Cities, Bicycle for the Mind, and Beckham
summary: The US government has updated its export controls on AI chips, expanding its authority to determine what products US companies can sell in the name of national security. The updated rules ban shipments of high-end AI chips, including those developed by Nvidia and Intel for the Chinese market, without a license. Even high-end gaming chips are now more closely monitored. Nvidia has stated that the short-term impact on its results won't be significant due to high demand elsewhere, but losing more of the Chinese market in the long term will change the company's addressable market. The updated rules aim to prevent the misuse of chips to undermine US national security.

title: Deep Dive: Dollar Tree (DLTR) - Part 1
summary: Dollar Tree shares offer an attractive entry point for investors, with a 3-year target price of $200, according to a report by Value Punks. The report highlights the growth potential of the dollar store industry, which has been steadily taking share in retail for decades. Dollar stores offer a difficult-to-replicate value proposition that is insulated from e-commerce competition. Dollar Tree, in particular, has self-help opportunities to improve sales productivity and operating efficiency. The report also praises the management team, led by Chairman/CEO Rick Dreiling, who has a track record of success in the industry. The market is currently extrapolating recent issues at Dollar General to Dollar Tree, but the report argues that Dollar Tree is contributing to Dollar General's woes and is ahead in its investment cycle. The report concludes that Dollar Tree has an attractive return profile, with a target price range of $190-230/share and a 3-year IRR range of 23-30%.

title: Who’s Borrowing and Lending in the Fed Funds Market Today?
summary: The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) communicates monetary policy through the federal funds rate, which is the rate for short-term lending and borrowing of central bank reserves in the U.S. The market for federal funds has changed since the global financial crisis, with a decrease in daily trading volume. The main borrowers in the fed funds market are the U.S. branches and agencies of foreign banks (FBO branches), while domestic banks also borrow but at smaller volumes. FBO branches borrow in the fed funds market because they have limited access to deposits and face lower borrowing costs compared to domestic banks. Domestic banks increase their borrowing when aggregate reserves decline. The main lenders in the fed funds market are the Federal Home Loan Banks (FHLBs), which lend to their members through collateralized loans. FHLBs hold liquidity portfolios and do not earn interest on their balances at the central bank, creating an incentive for them to lend at rates below the interest on reserve balances (IORB) rate. Domestic depository institutions also lend in the fed funds market but at small volumes due to their ability to earn the IORB rate. Overall, the fed funds market has changed significantly since 2008, with the Fed's balance sheet expansion and the introduction of interest on reserve balances.

title: Spending Down Pandemic Savings Is an “Only-in-the-U.S.” Phenomenon
summary: Household saving rates in the United States and other high-income economies increased during the pandemic due to reduced spending and government income support. However, saving behavior has diverged since then, with the U.S. saving rate dropping below pre-pandemic levels while saving rates in other countries remain above pre-pandemic levels. As a result, U.S. consumers have been spending down their excess savings while excess savings in other countries remain untapped. This divergence helps explain why U.S. GDP has returned to its pre-pandemic trend path while GDP levels in other high-income economies remain below trend. The drawdown in U.S. excess savings has contributed to U.S. GDP growth, while weak consumer spending has acted as a drag on the recoveries of other countries. The reasons for this divergence in saving behavior are unclear, but it may be related to differences in the drivers of excess saving, such as unexpected income windfalls in the U.S. The spending down of excess savings in the U.S. has supported growth despite lagging real income and tighter financial conditions.

title: Do Large Firms Generate Positive Productivity Spillovers?
summary: Large firms, including both domestic and multinational companies, generate positive total factor productivity (TFP) spillovers to their domestic suppliers, according to a study by Mary Amiti, Cédric Duprez, Jozef Konings, and John Van Reenen. The study, which used firm-to-firm transaction data for Belgian firms between 2002 and 2014, found that firms that started selling to a "superstar" firm experienced around 7 to 8 percent higher TFP than firms that did not have a relationship with a superstar firm. The spillovers were observed for all types of superstar firms, including large firms, multinationals, and exporters. The study also found that forming relationships with superstar firms led to increases in sales, intermediate inputs, labor, capital, and the number of buyers for supplier firms. The spillovers were attributed to factors such as the transfer of know-how, access to new networks of potential customers, and signaling effects. The findings suggest that allowing superstar firms to grow and form relationships with less successful firms can have advantages for the economy.

title: Racial Discrimination in Child Protective Services
summary: A recent study has found significant evidence of racial disparities in the placement of children into foster care in the United States. Black children are 50% more likely to be placed into foster care than white children who have the same potential for experiencing maltreatment if left at home. The study used a quasi-experimental approach to measure unwarranted racial disparities by examining the placement rates of case investigators in Michigan. The findings suggest that racial discrimination may be a factor in the disparities observed. However, it is also important to consider the risk of subsequent maltreatment when assessing the placement disparities. The study found that the disparities were driven by children who had a potential for maltreatment if left at home. The research also suggests that higher placement rates among Black children may offer protection to those at risk of maltreatment. The study highlights the need for policies that aim to reduce racial disparities in foster care placement and improve family well-being.

title: How Has Treasury Market Liquidity Evolved in 2023?
summary: The article discusses the evolution of liquidity in the U.S. Treasury securities market in 2023. The market experienced a worsening of liquidity in March 2023 after the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, but quickly improved to levels similar to the previous year. Liquidity in the market is important for various purposes, including financing the U.S. government, managing interest rate risk, and implementing monetary policy. The article examines three commonly used measures of liquidity: bid-ask spread, order book depth, and price impact. These measures indicate that liquidity worsened in March 2023 but returned to levels similar to the previous year within a month. The increase in volatility due to the failures of the banks explains the observed patterns in liquidity. The analysis also shows that liquidity in 2023 is consistent with the historical relationship between liquidity and volatility. The article concludes by emphasizing the need for continued vigilance and efforts to enhance the market's resilience.

title: An Update on the Health of the U.S. Consumer
summary: Consumer spending in the US has been stronger than expected, with real personal consumption expenditures (PCE) growing faster than predicted. The strength of consumption can be attributed to factors such as the fast rollout of vaccines, larger-than-expected fiscal stimulus, and low interest rates. While there is uncertainty about the level of excess savings accumulated by households during the pandemic, a broader assessment of households' financial positions is more important than excess savings alone. The role of debt in supporting consumption is examined, with households benefiting from lower mortgage payments and cash-out refinances. Other forms of debt, such as student loans and credit cards, have also contributed to available funds for consumption. Indicators of households' financial health, such as delinquency rates and consumer expectations, suggest that the household sector is in a strong position. However, the end of very low interest rates and the resumption of student loan payments may tighten household finances in the future.

title: Borrower Expectations for the Return of Student Loan Repayment
summary: The end of the federal student loan payment pause has led to an analysis of borrower expectations regarding the impact of the payment resumption on future spending growth, credit delinquency, and the economy. The findings suggest that the resumption of payments will have a relatively small overall effect on consumption, with a 0.1 percentage point reduction in aggregate spending from August levels. Student loan delinquency rates are expected to return to pre-pandemic levels. Low-income borrowers, female borrowers, those with less than a bachelor's degree, and those who were not in repayment before the pandemic are more likely to expect missed student loan payments. The survey also reveals that enrollment in income-driven repayment (IDR) plans is expected to increase, particularly among low-income borrowers. Borrowers anticipate a decrease in average monthly spending of around $56 per month when payments resume. The likelihood of missing a student loan payment is higher for female borrowers and those with lower household incomes. However, expectations for missing non-student loan payments are more similar across groups. Overall, the impact of the payment resumption on consumption and delinquency is expected to be relatively modest, partly due to borrowers already adjusting their savings and consumption decisions in anticipation of the resumption.

title: Can China Catch Up with Greece?
summary: China is unlikely to achieve its goal of reaching the per capita income of a mid-level developed country by 2035, according to economists Hunter L. Clark and Matthew Higgins. They argue that China's rapid growth is facing challenges such as population aging, diminishing returns to its investment-centered growth model, increased state management of the economy, credit issues in real estate, and limited access to foreign technologies. Even with generous assumptions about future growth, China is projected to close only a fraction of the income gap with high-income countries. The authors also highlight the constraints on China's future growth, including declining labor inputs due to population aging and diminishing returns to capital accumulation. They argue that achieving the necessary productivity growth to meet income goals is unlikely, given that China's productivity growth is already high and historical precedents show that very few countries have achieved such growth rates. Additionally, the authors point out the structural headwinds, such as state management of the economy, institutional development, the need to rebalance the economy, and high levels of private and government debt. The authors conclude that while China has strengths, such as a well-educated population and technological advancements, the odds of achieving the income growth target are stiff.

While some argue that buybacks are superior to dividends due to tax advantages and the potential for share value appreciation, the author believes that dividends are a more reliable and beneficial option. They argue that buybacks can be unpredictable and may not always increase shareholder value. The author prefers dividends because they provide a steady income and the option to reinvest the cash. They also highlight the importance of a company's history of both dividends and buybacks when analyzing investment opportunities. The article concludes by stating that while a consistent share buyback can be powerful and beneficial for dividend growth, it is not always the best capital allocation choice, and other factors such as reinvestment potential or acquisitions should also be considered.
